text: Darkness. The sound of battle cries and the clang of meta upon metal. The forest lights up with huge sparks flying  from sword and ax as armored knights hack and swing at ea other. Mounted knights collide head-on at full gallop, th armor made incandescent in the clash. Sparks eddy in thei wakes and float to the ground. The forest catches fire. MAIN TITLES on the flames. Out of the sounds of ancient b grows music, heroic and barbaric, shot through with  melancholy. Two crazed eyes reflect the fire. The eyes belong to a ma without age, at once ancient and boyish, female and male; his eyes are pained from the burden of too much knowledge So close is he to the flames that a lock of his wild hair sizzles alight. He slaps at the fire as if it were an ann insect. He wears a cloak of black trimmed with silver. It Merlin. The wizard weaves a path through the burning fore dodging the combatants, searching.
Lord Uther! Lord Uther!

The forest around him weeps softly with the sounds that f slaughter. Patches of undergrowth are smoldering. Small f lick bark and branches. Smoke floats through the trees and hovers over the bodies the dying and the dead. A huge knight reins up beside Merlin on a lathered horse. His armor is blood spattered. He is weary from battle. He looks down at Merlin, his countenance fierce. The blade o his sword glows with an unnatural aura.
It's done. A truce. We meet at the  river.
(disgusted) Talk. Lovers murmuring to each  other...

Waiting on one bank of a small river that flows through t forest is a warlord, the Duke of Cornwall. He is flanked his armored warriors. Lot of Lowthean prominent among the They are battle-weary and bloodied, but they look ready t fight. Behind them is an army of lesser knights. To the opposite bank come Uther and Merlin, a much smalle force of knights, including Uryens, Lord of Gore, surroun them.
I spit on your truce, Uther. If you  want peace, throw down your swords.
Uther and the Duke of Cornwall glare at each other in sil across the river. Uther strains forward, burning with ang but Merlin restrains him.
I should butcher all and every one  of them. Merlin, what is this wagging  of tongues?
Just show the sword.

Uther unsheathes his mighty sword, and brandishes it in t air high over his head. The blade hums disquietingly and  leaves a lingering electric hue upon the air. The marvel  instills dread in all present.

(waxing eloquent) Behold the sword of power, Excalibur.  Before Uther, it belonged to Lud,  before Lud, to Beowulf, before Beowulf  to Baldur the Good, before Baldur to  Thor himself and that was when the  world was young and there were more  than seven colors in the rainbow. (and in an aside to  Uther) Speak the words.
(bellowing) One land, one king! That is my peace!
The Duke of Cornwall looks around nervously as some of hi knights fall to their knees in awe.
Lord Uther, if I yield to the sword  of power, what will you yield?
Me, yield!?
Merlin urges Uther hard.
(a whisper) He has given. Now you must.
The two knights glare at each other, rage contending with anger.
The land from here to the sea is  yours if you will enforce the King's  will.
The enemies lock eyes and Merlin watches anxiously.
Done!
All men from both sides break out in wild cheers.
My Lord King Uther, let us feast  together. To my castle. Lord Merlin,  you must join -
But Merlin is nowhere in sight.

Drums and wailing flutes fill the banquet hall with a lus rhythm. Armored warriors watch a lone woman dancing. She very beautiful, both sensuous and innocent. Uther sits at the long table beside the Duke of Cornwall  with the barons and dukes of the land, and the lesser kni The table is stained with wine and littered with bones an half-eaten fruit. Uther's eyes burn with lust as he watches the dancer.
I would wish you such a wife, Lord  Uther, as my Igrayne. So innocent,  but in bed, a furnace...
The Duke rises and goes to his wife, be-striding the cent of the hall and Igrayne weaves circles of dance around hi He gloats with pride. The words escape his lips:
I must have her.
Lot spins to face him.
What? You're mad! What about the  alliance?
(oblivious) I must have her.
And risk all you've won? This castle  commands the sea gate to the kingdom.

Uther is not one for politics, and Lot's words sail past  him. The King lusts for Igrayne. A bell is struck not far away. The music ceases and the h falls silent. The great door creaks open, revealing the d light, and a monk steps into the hall and waits by it. Mu by corridors of stone, a choir of monks can now be heard  singing the high, ecstatic harmonies of the Te Deum. Thos who have fallen asleep at the table are roused, those dru helped up.

The monk leads the party down the hallway of the castle.  Thin shafts of dawnlight filter through archers' slits in the thick walls onto stone floors. Otherwise, it is dark. Each person, lady and knight, proceeds alone, head bent,  some crossing themselves. Uther is among them. He stops in a dark alcove, breathing heavily, waiting. As the lovely Igrayne drifts past him, he pulls her out o sight of the others. In a shaft of pale light Uther clasps Igrayne to his  breastplate, his iron arm wrapped around her frail body. violent is his embrace that she cannot breathe, her mouth wide with fear, and her feet do not touch the ground; an  impaled butterfly.
You will be mine. Wife and queen,  bed and crown.
His face is close to hers, looking as though he would dev her tender whiteness with his kiss. She doesn't answer; s can't. Even Uther understands this and lets her go.
(a fierce whisper) I want no other crown and no other  bed than those I have.
Her gown and her fragile skin torn on the spikes of his a Igrayne backs away and joins the procession. Uther trembles with unreleased passion.

Igrayne enters the candlelit chapel from which issues the chant, calling the castle to worship. She rushes to her  husband's side, kneeling next to him and whispering. The  Duke of Cornwall looks back at Uther, hatred in his eyes.

Uther is in a towering rage. Sword drawn, he stalks among the biers of fallen knights. Squires and clerics keep a  healthy distance. The sky is lowering, pregnant with roll thunder. Beyond his encampment, high on a cliff rising ou of the sea stands the impregnable Tintagel Castle, seat o the Duke of Cornwall, now under siege.
(bellowing in all  directions) Merlin! Where are you!?
Just then a knight rides up and dismounts. It is Ulfius, lieutenant.
Have you found him?
No--
But he cannot finish. He is taken aback by the sudden  appearance of a hideous hag who approaches, rattling a  beggar's pan.
What a hurry you were in this morning,  good sir. You forgot to give this  old woman a coin.
I saw you half a day's gallop from  here. I asked you if you had seen  Merlin. I returned here straight  away. How did -
--I heard. I have come. I am also  Merlin.
The figure straightens, the filthy rags become a flowing  cape, and the hair is swept back by the wind, andoit is  Merlin, laughing.
I have walked my way since the  beginning of time. Sometimes I give,  sometimes I take. It is mine to know  which, and when.
(exploding) Dumb riddles, Merlin. I am your King.
Ulfius edges away.
I know the storm inside you, and  what it has wrought. The alliance I  forged is wrecked.
The Duke of Cornwall under siege. All this for lust. Self lust. Uther grabs Merlin.
For Igrayne. One night with her. Do  it. Use the magic.
Merlin frowns pensively, his gaze searching strange dista and wandering; then focusing, blazing straight at Uther.
You will swear by your true kingship  to grant me what I wish. Then you  shall have it.
Uther kneels and draws his sword and holds it up by the b a cross.
I swear it. By Excalibur and the  holy--
--What issues from your lust will be  mine. Swear it again.
I swear it.
Merlin looks down sorrowfully at the kneeling King.
The Duke of Cornwall watches a force of armored knights r forth from Uther's war camp, with banners flying. It pass beneath the castle and on toward a distant cliff.
(to a lieutenant) It's Uther and all his best knights.  He leaves behind little more than  fledglings to guard his camp.
His eyes are as cold and as pale as ice.

Uther and his knights, and Merlin on a mule, ride to the  high promontory and dismount. Here, overlooking the sea, a circle of ancient stones, carved with strange runes and hieroglyphics, and as the wind moves through them it moan and sighs. The knights watch as Merlin and Uther, leading his horse, walk toward the stones. Merlin strides into the circle,  turning to look at Uther, who hesitates.
Come.

Uther starts to make the sign of the cross, but Merlin ha him with a gesture. Uther's hand drops, and he enters the circle with his horse. Merlin and Uther look out across the sea, to Tintagel Cas high upon the cliff. Merlin solemnly raises his arms toward that distant castl and chants in an ancient language, the sounds of which he marries to the roaring and whining of the wind. The wind  becomes stronger, and Merlin's incantations become more  intense, and the wind in turn becomes wilder still. Until Merlin is charged with a fierce, nonhuman power, as the w buffets his slight frame. And then, for all to understand:
I hold the balance of all things in  my summoning. Arise mists. Come fog.
From the horizon a front of fog advances toward the castl to envelop it, and continues across the gulf to the circl of stones.
The portal opens and a small force of armored men, led by the Duke of Cornwall, exits. A fog is thickening all arou them.
The advancing front envelops Merlin and Uther, eddying ar the stones.  All else is obliterated.
Mount your horse.
The King does.
Ride straight to the castle, across  the sea of fog.
Uther spurs straight for the edge of the cliff, then rein in his horse abruptly.
But the cliff, the sea...
Merlin rages, crazed.

Ride across! Across the bridges of  desire. Your lust will hold you up.  For I have just woven it into the  fabric of the world. This is magic -  making solid what is in the mind,  and unsolid, that which is already  solid.

He gives the horse a stinging blow with his staff. The horse and Uther charge forward into a gallop and step off where the hidden edge of the cliff would be, hoofbeat ceasing and the horse dropping for the blink of an eye, t gallop across the fog.
Galloping on no visible terrain, Uther and his horse adva through the restless fog, and as they recede rider and an become a wavering, changeable form within the cloud.
Horse and rider pull up at the gate.
(calling) Wake up in there. It is I.

If it was not for the electric blue hue burning in the ey of the man entering the castle, the same magic hue that  Excalibur left upon the air when wielded, the resemblance the Duke if Cornwall would be perfect. After a moment the portal opens.
He passes into an inner court, the portal closing behind. Armed men emerge cautiously. Thinking that it is their Du they help him dismount.
Have the horse ready. I ride out  before sunrise.
An inner gate opens and the 'Duke' goes through it.

The real Duke and his men ride through the fogbound camp, cutting the ropes of the tents, stabbing the men trapped  beneath the canvas. When a frightened crow flies squawkin into the face of the Duke's horse, which rears. He is unh and falls, and impales himself on a tent stake. Dying, the true Lord of Tintagel Castle rises and stagger forward, blood pumping from him.
A little girl of four awakens from a nightmare, a small l figure in her canopied bed. Her eyes are ice, like her  father's.
Papa... Papa...
Igrayne is soon at her side, lifting the child from the b holding her tight.
My father is dead...
The 'Duke' enters. The room is empty, but the door to  Morgana's room is open.
The 'Duke' stands in the doorway. Igrayne herself is  surprised.
Look, here is your father. It was  just a dream, little one.
Come Igrayne.
Igrayne kisses Morgana, tucks her in and returns to her o room, closing the door. The child doesn't know whether to believe the truth of the dream or the waking truth.

In full armor, the 'Duke' bears down on the naked Igrayne her marriage bed. She stares at him, wondering. But his e are closed, and finally he carries her in his wild passio her white limbs tangling around the lustre of his armor.
And Merlin is jolted awake from deep within himself, comi out of a trance.
It is done. The future has found  root in the present.

He lifts himself up on his staff. He stands in the midst the ancient stones, bristling with excitement. Uther's mi knights are asleep, a deep unnatural sleep, huddled toget and surrounded by their horses. And then Merlin swoons,  collapsing to the ground.

His lieutenants deposit the Duke of Cornwall's bloodless  body upon the long table. His eyes are wide open, icy and cunning even in death. The ladies of the castle support a comfort the grief-stricken Igrayne as she approaches the  body of her husband. Morgana hangs onto her mother's gown
When did it happen? Where?
In the camp of Uther, my lady, just  after nightfall.
It can't be. He came to me, to his  bed, last night.
It was his spirit, yearning for you  in his hour of death, that visited  you.
His spirit?
Pale with grief, Igrayne stares at her dead husband in  silence. Then her hand drifts to her stomach. When she talks again undone and resolved, it is to all and herself:
Tintagel Castle falls to Uther. But  what shall become of me, and the  child I bear?
Morgana shows no distress. She runs her baby hands across her father's face and closes his eyes. The intensity that was frozen in them is now added to her own pale and cunni eyes.
Merlin has been propped up against one of the stones. He in a deep trance and Uther is attempting to shake him awa
I want her, Merlin. I cannot be  without her. Tintagel is mine. Can I  take her now? Tell me!
Merlin's eyes open but he sees nothing, and only a puzzli squeal issues from him.

head_text.subj: INT. IGRAYNE'S BEDCHAMBER, TINTAGEL CASTLE- EVENING

text: Morgana watches from a corner. The ladies of the castle  surround Igrayne who is giving birth. Noisy crows alight on the windowsill. Only Morgana notice
Uther strides to Igrayne's bedchamber, his warrior knight following. He is dirty and his iron dress is blood-spatte
(bellowing) Three horses died under me, so hard  did I spur them here. Is it born? Is  it alive?

At his approach and entrance the ladies shrink back, and  Morgana edges closer to her mother, and seats herself on bed beside her. Ingrain holds her newborn baby in her arm the blood of birth still wet upon it.
Out!
The ladies slip past him to the door, and he goes up to  Igrayne.
What is it, lady?
Terrified of him, Igrayne faces him the best she can.
A boy, sir. Rest yourself.
Uther waves away her words but does sit down on the bed,  exhausted. He notices Morgana, who stares at him.
Send the girl away.
She is just a child -
Out!
Igrayne draws the child to her and kisses her cheek.
(whispering) Go now. Come back later.
The child leaves silently, hatred in her eyes.
She watches me with her father's  eyes.
He grasps the newborn baby with his iron hand, and pulls to himself. He looks upon it with wonder, with a gentlene that is unexpected.
Igrayne, is he mine, or -
He can't bring himself to say his name. She hesitates on edge of tears, worried for the infant lying in its iron  cradle.

The night he died, a man loved me  with great fierceness. He looked  like my husband, spoke like, smelled  like, felt like my own husband. But  it was not he, for he was already  dead. It wasn't his spirit, for this  child, who was conceived that night,  is flesh and blood. I know nothing  more.
Uther draws a dagger. He lifts it.
No--

But he uses it before Igrayne can move. He severs the lea thongs that bind the iron breastplate to his chest. He ca it to the floor. His chest is smooth and milk-white in  striking contrast to his creased, weathered face. And bea he holds the baby to it.
Through him, I will learn to love  them, for I am tired of battle. I  will stay by his side and (looking shyly at  Igrayne) his mother's...
Igrayne's hatred for the man is at the very edge of becom love. The baby starts to cry.
Here. It's hungry.

And his free hand opens her shift, and he holds a swollen breast in his gloved hand, squeezing gently. Milk bubbles from it and he thrusts the baby's mouth onto it. Igrayne weeps and Uther watches proudly as the baby suckl Merlin advances from the window, his cape the same irides green-black as the feathers of the crows that were perche by the window.
Merlin! Out of the sick sleep at  last.
Doing what I did for you, it wasn't  easy, you know. It takes it's toll.  It took nine moons to get back my  strength.
Uther avoids looking at him.
Now you must pay me.
I?
The child is mine, Uther. I have  come for him.
Uther is shaken to his roots. Igrayne watches, trying to  understand.
The oath. You didn't say--
You didn't ask!
Uther, is it true? Don't let him  take the child.
I swore an oath, Igrayne. I made a  pact with Merlin.
Igrayne suddenly understands. She glares at Uther.
It was you? You came to me that night.  You are the father.
Uther is caught, and turns to Merlin who is harsh and  unswaying.
It's not for you, Uther, hearth and  home, wife and child.
To kill and be king, is that all?
Maybe not even that, Uther. I thought  once that you were the one to unite  the land under one sword. But it'll  take another, a greater king...
You strike me with words as hard as  steel.

They are not weapons, my friend, but  truths. You betrayed the Duke, stole  his wife and took his castle, now no  one trusts you. Lot, Uryens, your  allies will turn against you. Give  me the child, Uther, I will protect  him. Go back to your war tent.
Uther wrenches the baby from it's mother's breast and han him to Merlin.
(in torment) By the oath, take the devil child.  Take him!
With the bawling baby under his cape, Merlin exits. Igray pulls herself out of the bed, weak, her legs giving under her. She starts after Merlin.
WHY?... Why must he have the baby?
Uther stops her with his bulk and she claws savagely at h chest to get past him. He weeps as he folds his arms arou her.

As Merlin walks through the castle, the baby crying in hi arms, the knights and ladies step back, afraid to interve in royal matters. INT. HALL, TINTAGEL CASTLE - NIGHT. Merlin comes across the empty banquet hall, cooing to the baby, strangely pacifying him. Morgana steps out of the  shadows in his path, and Merlin stops at the sight of the little girl, her pale eyes glaring at him. She speaks haltingly and clearly while far-off Igrayne cr out her distress.
Merlin, are you now the father, and  the mother, of the baby?
Staring at her, Merlin shudders and without answering he  continues away, faster now, and into an unlit passageway, disappearing from sight a bit sooner than an ordinary mor would have.

The forest is dark and shiny with rain. An unseen battle  rages. The first combatant in sight is Uther, who swings the mig Excalibur, cutting an attacker in half at the waist. Uthe and a small force of knights, Ulfius among them, are  retreating through the slippery wet forest, completely  outnumbered. Lord Lot of Lowthean and Lord Uryens of Gore are the lead of the attack.
(to his men) The King's sword. I must have it.
Ulfius and his men stand their ground so the King may esc the onslaught. They are hacked down. Uther flees alone, severing the limbs of any man and tree that stands in his way.

Uther has gained on his pursuers. He comes to a small cle where the spine of a buried boulder rises through the for floor. He stops upon it, breathing hard, dripping blood. rages aloud, but his throat is raw and cracked and only a whisper comes out.
Merlin, where are you? To weave a  mist, to hide us...
He hears his pursuers closing in.
No one shall have the sword. No one  shall wield Excalibur but me.

He holds it by the hilt with both hands, the blade pointi to the ground of stone. He flexes his knees. He lifts up hands above his head. And with all the strength that rage and pain can muster, and more, he drives the blade of  Excalibur into the stone, nearly to the hilt. His mouth w in an awful silent scream, and then the foam of saliva pi with blood issues from deep within him, so violent was hi effort. As the sword cuts into the rock, the earth shudders.
The forest quakes. The knights searching for Uther halt i fear.

And far away, a caped figure is crossing a field toward a wood, when the earth shakes, stirring animals and birds. man turns. He is Merlin, the two day-old baby peeking fro his cape. Merlin is amazed at the phenomenon, he puts his ear to a rock protruding from the earth.
Into the spine of the dragon! (and then he is  saddened) Uther... I loved you, mighty child.
And tears welling, and giggling at the same time, he whis away into the woods.

Uther staggers away, colliding with trees, staggering,  crashing to the ground. Until the only life left in him i the coursing of his blood, flowing from his gaping mouth  onto the leaves on the forest floor. The enemy knights advance through the trees. They prod at the fallen leviathan, they roll him over to get at his  scabbard. Only then do they see the sword in the stone, a they stop, amazed and afraid. Their captains appear. Urye sees what they are staring at, and races to the sword and attempts to pull it out. He strains with all his might, but it is immovable.
Let me.
He shoves Uryens aside, but he can't loosen the sword eit and he rages with frustration.
"Fifteen years passed and the land was without a king."

Peasants spill over the crest of a hill. They are fleeing force of armored knights, their plumed helmets forged in semblance of predatory animals. The knights thunder past peasants, trampling the ripening crops. Sir Uryens is the leader, his hard face indifferent to the havoc he leaves his wake. The peasants watch in mute anger.

Sir Lot leading another group of mounted knights comes  galloping into a small hamlet, panicked chickens and pigs scattering at their approach. The farmers run for their l as the steel men dismount, leading their horses to water hay, and searching for vittles. A knight spots a woman wh stands frozen with fear, and he drags her into the barn a her crying child watches.

A farmhouse is burning nearby, and three mounted figures  make their way along a trail at a walking pace - an old k in leather and mail, a young knight proud in gleaming new armor; and on a farm horse, a squire with baggage and jou lance. The old knight, Sir Ector, is troubled by what he  sees.
It is a dark hour... everywhere  lawlessness and destruction, and no  one to lead us out of it.

Just then, ten crazed peasants emerge from the darkness,  hurling stones and armed with clubs and pronged sticks. T surround the three riders. Sir Ector wheels around and sl the air with his sword to ward off the ambushers.
Listen all. I am Sir Ector of Morven  and these are my sons. You would  wrong me, for I have never stolen  from others, or destroyed the fruit  of the land.

The peasants edge closer, working up the nerve to rush th horsemen. The sound of thundering hooves cuts through the clamor. A cavalcade of riders, armor gleaming in the moonlight,  advances across the fields at a gallop. Immediately the  peasants scatter. The old knight is on the verge of tears
The people's anger is just. It is  sad that for our own safety, we will  have to ride to the tournament with  these robber knights.

location: SITE OF THE SWORD IN THE STONE

text: Red with the first light of day, Excalibur rests in the s as King Uther left it. The field is itched with tents, ea flying its heraldic banner. Knights and squires are  everywhere, preparing horses and armor for the joust. A b man in religious robes harangues the crowd, vying for  attention.
This is Easter day, when Christ rose  again. Who will find strength in  victory of arms? Who will draw the  sword?

The Bishop goes among the tents, through the teeming thro solemnly casting holy water upon man and horse, armor and banner. The knights kneel at the Bishop's transit, but  ceremony does not lift the air of grimness that lies over the event.

location: JOUSTING GROUND, SWORD IN THE STONE

text: Their armor ablaze with sunlight, two mounted knights thu toward each other at full gallop, lowering their long jou lances. As they meet, the lance of each knight is deflect by the shield of the other. A gasp goes through the crowd and the two knights charge past each other. They wheel ar at the end of the jousting ground and go at each other ag from the other direction. Again lances strike, and this t one of the men is hit in the chest and violently unhorsed The crowd cheers.

The victor, Leondegrance, rides up to the stone and dismo Each great knight with his coterie of lesser knights come to watch. A charge of expectation is in the air, although most knights are glowering with envy. Leondegrance of Camelyarde ascends to the sword, grabs it the hilt, and begins to tug with all his might. Excalibur immovable. The moment of tension passes. Leondegrance sta toward his waiting squires, who lead him away. All the ot return to the battle sport.

At the edge of the jousting ground Sir Ector's son Sir Ka is getting ready for a bout. His brother Arthur is buckli the new armor while his father fusses about him, making s adjustments when he notices that Kay's scabbard is empty. turns to Arthur and grab's him by the ear.
Arthur, where is Kay's sword? A good  squire doesn't forget his knight's  sword.
The fifteen year-old boy blushes.
I left it in the tent, sir.
Well hurry then, and get it.
The boy dashes off as Sir Ector shakes his head, not with affection beneath the sternness.
Arthur runs in search of their tent. He finds it.
He enters. The saddle trunk has been emptied on the floor equipment is scattered all over. Arthur is shocked,  nonetheless he rummages madly. Finally he stops, on the v of tears.
It's been stolen....

He comes out, utterly defeated, and frantic. He stops by knights who are arguing angrily; and one of them has left his sword in the grass. Arthur looks at it. He is tempted to steal it, but he can Head down, he wanders off.
Sir Ector and Sir Kay are waiting.
Father, I'll go and see what's keeping  him.

Arthur stops at the edge of the dark forest, totally deje when he sees the sword in the stone. He walks up to it, h face lighting up, brimming with innocence. He is alone, a everyone has returned to the jousting ground.
If only Kay could have it...

He smiles, forgetting his troubles, a boy again living in fairy tale. He grasps the sword by the hilt and it comes  away easily from its stone lock. Not expecting it to, he nearly falls. He stares at it,  terribly excited and surprised: he tucks it under his arm and rushes back.
He bumps into Kay.
(breathless) Your sword was stolen, Kay, but here  is Excalibur. Is it too late? I  hurried--
Kay takes it. He cannot believe what he's holding in his  hands. He starts to talk but he is so agitated he can onl stutter.
Kay, with Arthur in tow, rushes to Sir Ector and shows hi the sword; he trembles with excitement.
Look, Father. Excalibur. Does that  mean that I am to be king?
Sir Ector is dumbstruck.
Did you free the sword, boy?
I... did, Father.
Ector looks at his son amazed, wanting to believe but not able to.
We must go to the stone at once.

With Excalibur in hand Ector of Morven heads for the ston Kay following, and Arthur too, the boy flushed with excit but a little worried, not understanding what is happening The exchange between Sir Ector and Sir Kay has been overh Some have seen the sword in Sir Ector's hand. Rumor sprea like wildfire.

As Sir Ector ascends the stone, from all parts of the jou ground knights and squires, the Bishop and the clerics, a peasants too, press around. Ector lowers the blade into the tight cleft and Excalibur sinks to its original position.
Draw it, son!
Sir Kay grabs the hilt and pulls without conviction, and sword doesn't give. Eyes downcast, he lets go.
Sir, I didn't draw the sword. Arthur  gave it to me.
Arthur ?! (spinning around to  face him) How did you get the sword, child?
(frightened) Sir... Kay needed a sword. His was  stolen. I saw Excalibur, and... I  took it.
You freed it, son?
I did, Father. I beg your forgiveness.
He starts to kneel but Ector pulls him up.
Try the sword, Arthur.
Arthur is about to grasp the hilt when Uryens and Lot, an other nobles, Leondegrance of Camelyarde, and Sir Caradoc and Sir Turquine among the younger, stride up.
Stand back, Sir Ector, and take your  children.
We will try again.
Uryens, Lot, Leondegrance, Caradoc, Turquine - each in tu grapples with the sword, only to be defeated by its  immobility. The crowd around the stone is thickening with common folk.
Let the boy try the sword.
Let the boy try...
The demand is echoed by peasants and serfs. The great kni remain silent and bitter in their defeat. Sir Ector pushe Arthur to the sword.
Go ahead, boy. Don't be afraid.

The boy hesitates shyly, and then takes the hilt of Excal and pulls out the sword with a great sweep. The throng is stunned. Silence falls. Some kneel, followi the example of Sir Ector and Sir Kay, of the Bishop and  Leondegrance. The other nobles stay back, confused, afrai angered. Arthur stands there, little more than a boy, his cheeks  flushed, his soft hair ruffled by the wind, his eyes shin with exultation, awe, and fear. Then, as if gaining confi from the sword itself, he turns it in arcs above his head
We have our King, thanks be to God.
The commoners and some of the knights react with roaring  enthusiasm. The others draw closer to Uryens and Lot and  their supporters, closing ranks around them.
Please, Father, rise up. I was your  son before I became your King... if  I am King.
Sir Ector rises, tears streaming down his cheeks.
My Lord, you are King, all the more  because you are not my son, and I am  not your father.
This is quite a shock to the boy king, and to the onlooke
Who is, then?
I don't know. Merlin brought you to  me when you were newly born and  charged me to raise you as my own.  At first, I did so because I feared  Merlin, later because I loved you.
Merlin's name is on the lips of all those close by.
Who is Merlin?
Speak of the devil!...

From out of the forest strides Merlin, dramatic, cape flo eyes crazed as ever, laughing at his own entrance. A crow perched on his shoulder, and it squawks loudly. Annoyed w it, Merlin swooshes it away.
I am Merlin. Counselor to kings.  Wizard and beggar. Prophet and... (he drops it) I have feasted on thunderbolts, I  savored my death before I got myself  born. I--
Merlin interrupts himself when his eyes fall on the boy, is taking in his performance raptly, half awestruck, half amused.
Whose son am I?
You are the son of King Uther, and  the fair Igrayne... you are King  Arthur.
The suspicion and confusion and envy of the lords erupts.
Merlin, we haven't forgotten you.  This is more of your trickery.
You're trying to foist a boy of  dubious birth upon us. You want to  shame us?
Lord Leondegrance, join us against  the boy. Surely you can see he is  only Merlin's tool.
No. I, Leondegrance, Lord of  Camelyarde, saw the drawing of Uther's  sword, and witnessed no trickery. If  a boy has been chosen, a boy shall  be king.

The crowd of serfs and peasants cheer wildly, and their l suppressed anger against the nobles comes to the fore. Th dare to press up against them, fists hammering on their  shields as the chant Arthur King over and over. Dark and  scowling, full of rebellion, all the lords except Leondeg begin to withdraw their iron men surrounding them.
Bells toll the good news. People stream by to see the new king and join the celebration.

location: SITE OF THE SWORD IN THE STONE

text: Uryens and Lot, and Caradoc, Turquine, and the other lord have mounted, and are moving out, when from the rear guar bowman in Lot's service draws upon the unarmored figure o Arthur across the cheering crowd. The bowman lets the arr fly. It flies over the heads of the crowd, unseen. Except by Merlin at Arthur's side. He extends his arms ha up, his fists clenched tightly as if drawing urgently on power within himself. The sound of wings is heard as he f his arms. The arrow flies toward Arthur. Arthur sees the arrow coming right at him, when a swoopin crow plucks it out of the air. Arthur watches the crow flapping its wings, climbing swif the arrow in its beak, disappearing over the forest. Only has noticed. When he turns Merlin is no longer at his side; to the  puzzlement of all. And Arthur is all of a sudden terribly alone and afraid, as people from all sides clamor for his attention and guidance.
Arthur charges through the shadowy forest. He is in armor but it is only a light tunic of mail. Excalibur is sheath in a leather scabbard by his side. He is frantic and he c urgently.
...Merlin... Merlin...
His face shines with sweat, the horse is lathered. He  dismounts and continues on foot into denser, more tangled undergrowth.
Merlin!
A huge eye opens in the foreground of what had appeared t be shadow, bark and tufts of weeds is really Merlin's hea
You called, sir?
His voice is thin as he is awakening from a deep, exhaust sleep. Arthur finds him lying within the large gnarled ro of a great tree. The boy kneels before Merlin and lifts h hands and kisses them.
You saved me from the arrow...
(a flicker of mischief) But not from your destiny.
I want to thank you.
That's not why you came.
Arthur blurts it out:
Merlin, help me. I need your help. I  don't know how--
(irritated) 'Help me, Help me.' Help me get up.
Arthur helps Merlin up and the wizard stands unsteadily.

I'm tired. Doing magic takes its  toll, you know. My arms ache  terribly... (he makes flying  movements with his  arms and grimaces) Once--or is it yet to happen--I stood  exposed to the Dragon's breath so  that a man could lie one night with  a woman. It took me ten moons to  recover. I'm sure that story would  interest you, since... Well, we'll  have to talk about it another time.  You're too busy now.
The forest groans and creaks, alive with murmurs and shri calls.
It is whispered in the forest that... (he cups his ear with  exaggeration) ...Leondegrance's castle is under  siege by Lot and Uryens.
(pressing) Yes, yes, I know that. Everybody  does. Lord Leondegrance is my only  ally among the barons and the great  knights. I can't lose him.
Well there. You don't need me half  as much as you think you do. You  already know what must not happen.
(exasperated) I must find the means to save him,  then. I was hoping I could ask you  for a little magic help, but if it  makes you so tired...
Thank you.
Silence. Arthur tries again.
It's just that I have no experience,  and no men to speak of. How can I--
(suddenly fierce) Because you must! You and only you.  Have you forgotten that it was you  who freed Excalibur?
Just as suddenly, he is his amused, ironic self again.
Besides, it will be a good lesson. (giggling) The best, if it's not the last.
Arthur bows his head, confused and almost defeated. Merli steals a look at him, and puts his arm around the boy.
Maybe you'd like to meet the power  that gave you the sword?
He enjoys being cryptic.
How? Where?
In the great book.
What book is that?

(melodramatic) The book without pages. Open before  you, all around us. You can see it  in bits and pieces, for if mortal  men were to see it whole and all  complete in a single glance, why, it  would burn him to cinders.
What?!
The dragon! There...
A deep cleft at the edge of the forest, where far below l boils with a phosphorescence that lights up a great cloud billowing upward.
Coiled in the unfathomed depths, it  emerges...
Merlin points to the sky where roiling clouds appear to b unfurling of immeasurable wings.
...It unfolds itself in the storm  clouds...
A terrific wave batters a coastline, spray shooting up, a as the wave recedes it exposes dark rocks and deep crevic
...it washes its mane sparkling white  in the blackness of seething  whirlpools...
Merlin spins Arthur around, and they are transported into storm swept forest. Lightning strikes.
...its claws are the forks of  lightning... its scales glisten in  the bark of trees...
The trees shine with wetness, as a great wind tosses thei crowns, the branches groaning against each other.
...its voice is heard in the  hurricane...
Arthur is awestruck.
Arthur and Merlin are back in the same spot, having in fa never moved at all, but traveled on the spell of Merlin's words alone.
...it is so much more than a scaly  monster. It is Everything!
Arthur's eyes shine with the brilliance of the vision.
And if I am to be King of everything,  lord and commoner, beast, leaf and  rock, I must use its voice, its claws,  its power.

Leondegrance, Lord of Camelyarde, is shocked by what he s in the distance. His daughter Guenevere, a beautiful girl sixteen, draws close to him, terrified. With his survivin knights, Leondegrance is making his last stand. The walls have been breached, parts of the castle are burning.

A bellowing dragon advances. Its eyes burn, its scales gl from light shining from within. It snorts fire from its  nostrils. Uryens and Lot, Caradoc and Turquine, the great knights i command of the siege of Leondegrance's castle, back away  speechless as the monster descends upon their unprepared camp. All around them, squires and lesser knights flee in panic and confusion. Only a dozen or so remain with their leaders. The group b up against the swampy moat that surrounds the castle, wai with swords drawn. The dragon moves closer, and now it becomes apparent that is nothing more than a force of knights and footmen. Thei shields glinting in the moonlight are the dragon's scales torches its burning eyes. And the snorting flames from it nostrils are only Merlin doing a fire-eater's trick. The dragon form dissolves, and a banner rises bearing the emblem of the Dragon, and under it, Arthur and Ector and lead a charge of twenty knights. In Arthur's hands, Excalibur leaves an electric glow upon the air.
Father, it's the boy King.
It is. I will fight my way to his  side.

Arthur and his men charge into the enemy ranks. Lot's and Uryens' people are pushed into the moat. Although the wat is only waist-deep, the fallen, weighed down by their arm drown. The horses of the attackers are brought down, Arth among them. He pulls out from under it, limping. Bleeding form wounds, cutting, slashing, thrusting, he falls back  from the havoc of the charge. A small distance exists now between the foes, a brief res Uryens and Lot, exhausted, bleeding, and fierce in their  rage:
War-wise fighters, grown gray in  battle, checkmated by a boy.
It's Merlin's trickery, nothing more.  I won't swear faith to that wizard's  brat.
Arthur and his men have been joined by Leondegrance and h knights, few in number.
Let's finish this with a show of  force. We have no more tricks and no  more advantages.
He rushes alone at the enemy, shouting at the top of his  lungs, Excalibur flashing over his head, prepared to die.
Guenevere watches...
No...
No... Arthur--
The old knight rushes after the boy, sword drawn, to defe his flank, and the others follow, a battle cry issuing fr them that is terrifying in its fierceness.
...and when she can't watch any longer, she buries her fa in her hands.

Arthur fights like a wounded lion at the center of the sa melee of sword and shield, and once again the two sides f apart. Uryens and Lot are standing in the moat among the bodies their men, are reduced to eleven knights, all wounded. Arthur is flanked by twenty men at arms, most of them wou and trembling now beyond exhaustion with blood lust. Arth steps forward alone, and addresses his opponents.
You are in my hands, to slay or spare.  I need battle lords such as you.  Swear faith to me and you shall have  mercy.
Noble knights swear faith to a mere  squire?
Arthur turns, searching for Merlin. He spots him watching from a distance. They stare at each other, Merlin implaca Arthur's eyes pleading. It's obvious that Merlin isn't go to help.
You are right. I'm not yet a knight. (gaining strength) You, Uryens, will knight me.
He unsheathes Excalibur and goes forward, kneeling before Uryens and offering him the sword.
Then as knight to knight I can offer  you mercy.
(to himself) What's this, what's this?!
Arthur, kneeling, bows his head and Uryens steps up to hi his features set. He accepts the sword. Lot watches, a ma hope dancing in his eyes.
Guenevere watches, frightened for Arthur, not daring to  breathe.
Uryens stands towering above the boy. He smiles enigmatic He lifts Excalibur. Merlin is attempting to push through the crowded ranks to get to Arthur. He's frantic and worried for once.
I never saw this...
Uryens swiftly lowers the sword on Arthur's neck; with th flat of the blade he gives Arthur the three strokes.
In the name of God, of Saint Michael  and Saint George, I give you the  right to bear arms, the power to  mete justice.
Arthur looks up.
That duty I will solemnly obey as  knight and King.
Uryens is deeply moved.
Rise, my King. I am your humble  knight, and I swear allegiance to  the courage in your veins, for so  strong it is, it's source must be  Uther. I doubt you no more.

Arthur rises and Uryens kneels and kisses his hands. Sir  Ector turns away to hide brimming tears. Merlin pushes th finally, out of breath. Uryens embraces Leondegrance whil Lot and the other enemy knights kneel in turn and kiss  Arthur's hands.

The castle can be glimpsed through the trees. A clear spr bubbles from the ground, and the sun splashes leaf, bird, squirrel, and bee with golden light, and Arthur and Guene too. Guenevere is serious and intent on her work.
Owww...

With water from the spring, she is bathing a large cut on his chest that has been stitched closed. Wounds on his ar and one on a calf also show evidence of her neat sewing.  She's just finishing, and she dabs his chest with a dry c
It didn't hurt too much, did it?
Ye...
--I'm pretty good at stitchery. I've  sewn my father's wounds more than  once.
He starts to get up.
Careful! You'll have to stay still  for a few days or you'll tear them  open.
Arthur shivers at the thought.
But I have to leave tomorrow. The  forests are thick with rebels,  invaders plunder our shores...
--And damsels in besieged castles  are waiting to be rescued?
I didn't know Leondegrance had a  daughter.
Well, then, I shall tell you which  knights have maiden daughters, so  you can avoid their castles.
Arthur smiles at her, enjoying her jealousy, and it irrit her a little.
No, I think it's better if you just  stay here to heal. At least a week.
I'm going.
Quiet, or I'll sew up your mouth  too.

She touches his lips with hers, her eyelids fluttering sh He stares at her young beauty, and draws her into a long, slow kiss. A shrill almost human squeal pierces the air not far away Arthur pulls away startled, half-rising. Guenevere giggle
Would you rescue me from a fiery  dragon, sir?
She puts her arms around him, drawing him close again,  speaking in a half-whisper.
It's just a furry little rabbit that  took the bait and sprung the trap.
They smile at each other, about to kiss. As they come clo
You'll find him served up to you  tonight, cooked in a most excellent  sauce...

The soft beat of psaltery and the liquid flow of lute. A  serving platter bearing roast rabbit in rampant position carried across the hall. It is laid on the long raised ta before Arthur, who presides in the middle. He looks at it suspiciously and blushes, remembering the afternoon; and looks back at him accusingly with its cherry eye. Guenevere is dancing around her father, lovely, gliding,  sensual. She sees Arthur and the rabbit and laughs out-ri He twists off a leg of the rabbit and sinks his teeth int it to hide his embarrassment. Guenevere passes to another partner, smiling at him, radiant. Arthur watches her, his heart breaking. He is in love. Merlin leans close.
A king must marry, after all.
...of course...
Only then does he realize that Merlin has understood  everything. He is annoyed at being so transparent.
I love her. If she would be my queen,  my dreams would be answered.

(mischievous) There are maidens as fair, and fairer  than Guenevere. If I put my mind to  it, I could see them now, many of  them, weeping for love of you,  watching the hills for you coming  from the high towers of their castles.  Offering you their every favor. Rich,  clever--but if it is to be Guenevere,  so be it.
A shadow of doubt crosses Arthur's brow.
Who will it be? Put your mind to it,  then.
Guenevere. And a beloved friend who  will betray you.
(smiling) Guenevere...
You're not listening. Your heart is  not. Love is deaf as well as blind.
Guenevere approaches, smiling and coquettish. She slaps h hands, and a servant sets down a tray of pastries before  Arthur.
They are only for you, for in them I  mixed things that heal, but not too  quickly; and things that make limbs  sleepy, preventing escape, but keep  one's mind sharp.
She smiles at Arthur's embarrassment and confusion.
What's in them?
She takes a cake and bites into it.
It is an ancient mixture, containing  only soft, unborn grains, and flavored  with roses. The rest is secret.
Guenevere offers one to Arthur, and he hesitates, looking it.

Looking at the cake is like looking  at the future. Until you have savored  its bitterness and its sweetness,  its texture and its perfume, what do  you really know? And then, of course,  it will he too late.
Arthur bites into the cake, and Guenevere looks deep into his eyes.
Too late...
"...but for years war kept Arthur from thoughts of marria

War tents have been pitched beneath the majestic trees. N the banner of the Dragon a doe grazes. Arthur is older, i battle-scarred plate armor, pacing and angry. He is watch by his wounded and bruised knights--Kay, Uryens, Lot,  Leondegrance, Caradoc, and some new young faces among the ranks. No one talks. The harsh clank of its battle trappings announces the arr of a horse. All eyes watch it walk into the camp. A knigh is slouched in the saddle. Arthur runs to meet the horse, followed by squires and so of the knights. He eases the rider to the ground, unlaces his helmet. It Sir Ector, and his hauberk is badly dented. Tears burn in Arthur's eyes.
He is the mightiest and fairest of  knights.
We fought and won battles, and now  one man defeats all my knights? I  will go.
He pushes past the knights and goes to his horse. Kay ste in front of him.
A king must not engage in single  contest. I'll go again.
Arthur rises into the saddle and takes a jousting spear f the rack.
Where is Merlin?
The squires are silent. Arthur gallops off in the direction Sir Ector came from. knights are afraid for him.

His countenance grim, Arthur gallops along a trail border a plowed field when in it a scarecrow moves. It starts to run as stick-wielding farmers pursue it. It is Merlin. Ar turns off into the field, and at the sight of an armored  knight on a war horse, the farmers turn and flee. Merlin  stops to catch his breath.
(angry) I should have left you to fend for  yourself.
I had to weave a little enchantment  on the bees so I could get some honey,  and I didn't feel up to using any  more magic just yet. Anyway, I was  in less danger than you'll be in  today.
Arthur's hand is clenched tight around Excalibur's hilt.
So you were stealing their honey.  They should have killed you.
Come now. So much anger for such a  little crime? Are you sure there is  nothing else troubling you?
You know full well there is, and I  go to meet it now. Come witness my  revenge.
He offers his arm and Merlin hoists himself up behind the King.

A waterfall cascades into a pool. The spray casts a rainb Beneath it is a colorful confusion of flowers and budding trees, a place dreamlike in its beauty. Arthur, with Merlin behind, gallops along the edge of the pool. The trail widens into a field of grass. Arthur rein beside a pile of broken lances and twisted shields. Acros the field, pitched upon the trail is a war tent made of  diaphanous white silk, a sky blue banner above it. Merlin slides off and Arthur continues. From the tent, a knight with jousting lance rides forward meet him. His armor is so shiny it is a mirror. His eyes, seen through the open visor, seem to laugh. His speech is foreign, from across the sea. He is Lancelot of the Lake.
Good day to you, sir.
Move aside. This is the King's road,  and the knights you joined arms  against were his very own.
I await the King himself. His knights  are in need of training.
I am King, and this is Excalibur,  sword of kings from the dawn of time.  Who are you, and why do you block  the way?
I am Sir Lancelot of the Lake, from  across the sea. I am the best knight  in the whole of Christiandom, and I  look for the king who is worthy of  my sword's service.
--That is a wild boast. You lack a  knight's humility.
Not a boast, sir, but a curse. (a cloud passes over  his innocent face) Never have I met my match in joust  or duel.
Move aside!
I will not. You must retreat or prove  your kingship in the test of arms,  under the eyes of God.
He crosses himself.
Then may He give me the strength to  unhorse you and send you with one  blow back across the sea.

Arthur wheels away, trembling with anger, and gallops to edge of the field. He sees that Lancelot has already  positioned himself and is waiting, lance down. Merlin watches, a spectator, as the two charge at each ot They collide with great force, their spears shattering. A is jolted but stays in the saddle. Lancelot's jousting is impeccable. Arthur draws Excalibur.
Hold! I offer you another lance.
Pages come forward with new lances for Arthur and Lancelo
You joust well, sir. Battle learnt,  but tournament fancy. You should  ride more forward in the saddle,  though.

Arthur grabs the spear from the page's hands, and circles back to work the horse up into an all-out gallop. Lancelo spurs forward to meet him. Arthur is neatly unhorsed. He  picks himself up from the ground in a rage, drawing Excal Lancelot on his horse weaves circles around him.
Yield. I have the advantage.
I will not.
Arthur charges Lancelot, a raging bull, but cuts and slas only at the air as Lancelot stays clear of him.
Fight me from your horse or on foot,  but fight me. Your avoidance mocks  me.
I sought only not to harm you, sir.

He dismounts and draws his sword, and they clash. Shield sword and armor against shield and sword and armor. The  swordplay is furious, Arthur attacking, slashing, hacking Lancelot parrying effortlessly, elegantly defensive. Arth breaks the onslaught to catch his breath. Lancelot lifts visor. His eyes are calm, laughing.
Sir, your rage has unbalanced you.  It seems you would fight to the death  against a knight who is not your  enemy, for a length of road you can  ride around.
So be it, to the death.
It is you, sir, who knows not the  virtue of humility, as a true king  must.

Arthur goes forward attacking with terrible blows upon  Lancelot's shield, and Lancelot holds his ground, shield  high. And in its mirror-like metal Arthur can see his own reflection, a face distorted by uncontrolled passion. Arthur discards his own shield, grabs Excalibur with both hands, and with a frightening shout that speaks of all hi rage, he swings a terrific blow upon the shield, cutting  through his own reflection and the metal. And Excalibur s in two. A blinding blue-green light explodes from the broken swor Lancelot, knocked back by the force of the blow, is stunn by the blast and falls to the ground unconscious. Arthur  backs away, horrified, half of Excalibur in his hand.
What horror is this? (calling) Merlin!
Merlin approaches, pale, gripped by dread.
The sword is broken. Hope is broken...
Arthur picks up the broken blade, utterly undone.

My pride broke it, my rage broke  it... Humiliation and defeat lie in  ambush even for a king. (looking at Lancelot) This excellent knight who fought  with fairness and grace was meant to  win. With Excalibur, I tried to change  that verdict.
Merlin stands there, drawn, defeated, his hopes dead.
I have lost for all time the ancient  sword of my fathers whose power was  meant to unite all men, to serve the  vanity of a single man.
Despairing, he flings the two parts of Excalibur into the pool. He kneels at the waters edge, and he cries.
I am nothing.

Then Arthur sees something that startles him. Beneath the surface, suspended in the blue-green water amid the danci weeds, he sees Excalibur, intact. It is held by a maiden in flowing gown the color of water her long hair rippling across her face, obscuring it.
Excalibur! Is it true?
The Lady of the Lake. Take it. Take  it, quickly!

Arthur dips his hand under the water and grasps the hilt the moment he does the vision in the blue-green water fad He rises with Excalibur in hand, and Merlin speaks before Arthur can ask the question.

There are infinite worlds within the  infinite coils of the Dragon. In one  of them, which I have not traveled,  the sword was forged. I only know  that the King is returned to us  through the instrument of his power.  The game continues!

And he laughs. Just then Lancelot stirs. Arthur rushes to his side. He  loosens his helmet and removes it, uncovering damp curls. The young knight's eyes open, and his laughing charm once more animates his face.
Thanks to God, you are alive.
(sitting up) I, the best knight in the world,  bested! This is a great day, for my  search is over. I love you, my King.
He embraces Arthur, who is overwhelmed by his childlike  directness. The King helps him to his feet.
You are still the best knight in  Christiandom. You gained a hundred  advantages over me. It is I who must  love you, for through your courage  and patience you taught me a bitter  lesson.
Then make me your champion and I  will always fight in your place.
But your life and lands are far from  here.
I gave up my castles and my lands!
He thumps his breastplate.
My domain is here, inside this metal  skin. And I would pledge to you all  that I still own: muscle, bone, blood  and the heart that pumps it.
And a great heart it is. Sir Lancelot,  you will be my champion.
Lancelot draws his sword, holding it by the blade, a cruc
In the name of Jesus Christ and His  holy blood, I swear eternal faith to  Arthur, King.
They embrace, and Merlin watches.

Converging from different directions parties of mounted  knights enter the war camp. Lancelot among them. They  dismount, battle-weary and burning with the excitement of victory. They quench their huge thirst from buckets carri by squires. They rip off hunks of meat from carcasses siz on spits over a roaring fire. And they join the throng of knights, where stories of deeds of arms of the day are  enthusiastically exchanged. A great number of knights are packed tightly around King  Arthur, each man anxious to tell of his victories. One of them has the King's attention.
...We killed every one of them. Burnt  their ship...

Arthur sees Lancelot in the throng and moves toward him.  Merlin follows Arthur and is pushed and knocked around in the crush of spikes and iron. The only unarmored man in t crowd, he glares at the excited knights irritably.
Lancelot, how did you fare in the  North?
We spared the lives of a few, so  they could sail home and tell their  fellows what fate they met at the  hands of King Arthur's knights...
Arthur turns toward Uryens.
And you, Uryens?
Victory!
Lot, and you?
We drove the invaders into the sea.
You, Gawain, the East?
The East is ours again.
Cheers greet each declaration.
The war is over. One land, one King.  Peace.
Amidst the celebration, a fracas is heard. A knight pushi forward to talk to Arthur has entered a shoving match wit those in front of him.
Let me through. I fought the King's  battle too. He must know my story.

Merlin is brutally jostled. He draws a fistful of powder  from his cape and he tosses it into the air above him. He raises his staff into the cloud, cracking it like a whip. The tip of the staff catches fire, and the fire spreads  through the powder in the air, stunning all into silence. Merlin shouts and snarls.
Chaos... confusion... brutes...  savages... troglodytes... Stand  back... make space.
Merlin swings his burning staff into a wide arc. The knig back away, amused at first, then a bit afraid.
The moon... the sun... the stars...  they spin... they turn... they  circle... around us... us...
The knights have fallen back. Merlin stalks past each man and Arthur too, holding the flaming tip of his staff befo each pair of eyes, and staring into them with his gimlet  gaze.
You, and you, and you, take up your  place. Be wedded to the world. Respect  its perfection. All of you, together,  be one.

The knights have formed a circle. They realize this.  Awestruck, they whisper in astonishment, looking up at th sky burning with stars. Merlin brims with pride as he wai for Arthur to recognize his handiwork.

Your ancient wisdom and infinite  sight have forged this circle, Merlin.  Hereafter we shall come together in  a circle, to tell and hear of deeds  good and brave. I will build a table  where this fellowship shall meet.  And a hall around the table. And a  castle about the hall.
A cheer rises. Arthur strides into the ring of knights.
And I will marry.
Another bout of cheers goes up, and Arthur stops before  Leondegrance, resting his hand on the old knight's should
And the land will have an heir to  wield Excalibur.
Leondegrance's eyes fill with tears of joy. A roar of che Arthur draws the sword of power.

Knights of the Round Table, good  friends, brothers in arms. I send  you on a quest harder by far than  the battles we have fought together,  a quest to uphold always, and  everywhere, justice, honor, and truth.  Each day shall bring forth a cause,  and may each cause bring forth a  knight.
Lancelot is drawn in by the King's enthusiasm. He unsheat his sword and swoops it low in salute.
I swear never to rest twice on the  same pillow till all men live at  peace.

In quick succession all knights draw their swords, follow Lancelot's example. Merlin struggles to put out the flame on his staff. He fi does it by smothering it with earth. When he looks up aga he sees the knights galloping off in all directions.

Terrified women, a screaming child, cowering men, old or  made old by the hard labor of the fields. Armored men are ransacking a farm, looking for grain, and gold which they find among the votive objects of a little house altar. A  woman is dragged away to be raped. Through a window, a knight in shining armor is seen emerg from the adjoining woods. The plunderers are all of a sud apprehensive, and fall silent. One of them grabs the cryi child and covers her mouth with his iron hand.

The knight is Lancelot, in his mirror-like armor. He ride into the cluster of houses and barns that make up the far There are other armored men there, around a cart half-loa with loot. They smile nervously at Lancelot. The farmers blank with fear. Lancelot stops in the middle of the yard. A knight among armored men comes forward.
Good day, sir.
Good day to you.

And he also acknowledges with a nod the ashen-faced patri of the community. Lancelot spurs his horse on, and the knight sighs with re But then he reins his horse to a stop. He has sensed  something. He turns his head, his hooded eyes on the knig and his men, and they squirm inwardly.
The child, her mouth covered by the armored hand.
Lancelot, listening, watching.
The woman, a blade flashing next to her eye.
Lancelot, immobile. Behind him, the knight, his face shin with sweat. His minions inch forward, hands moving slowly toward sword hilts. Lancelot wheels his horse around.
I hear the stifled cry for help, I  smell the reek of fear...

With a shout the knight and his men draw their swords and rush Lancelot. He reins in his horse, causing it to rear break their attack. He slides off, falling on his feet wi sword drawn, already fighting. In an extraordinary show o sword play he cuts down six men.

Hearing Lancelot storm in, the man holding the child hand her to a woman and kneels before the altar, just as Lance bursts into the room, sword high and already swooping dow on the man's neck. Lancelot brings the sword to a halt mi air, his fury held in check. The repent man is spared. Th woman kneels to kiss Lancelot's hand.

location: SITE OF THE SWORD IN THE STONE

text: The field is pitched with war tents and pavilions decked holiday. Nobles and knights flank the King and Guenevere, beautiful vision in white samite, a wreath of flowers aro her head. Lancelot leads a long file of prisoners to the  King. They fall to their knees, begging forgiveness; amon them is the man whom Lancelot had spared before the altar
These men repented before God for  their evil deeds. Those who would  not, met their fate at the end of my  sword. (he kneels) Accept the fruit of my first quest  as my wedding gift.
I do. Rise, Lancelot, come with me.
He rises and follows Arthur and Guenevere into the centra pavilion. Pages draw its curtains closed as they pass ins

Guenevere is surrounded by a group of ladies and maids wh fuss over her dress and her hair. They eye the great knig and whisper about him, Guenevere laughing with them. Arthur sits, excited and happy.
Sit beside me, Lancelot.
Lancelot sits, stiff and upright.
Your deeds set an example for all  other knights. For your gift, ask a  gift of me.
Only give me leave to ride out again,  to do what I am most able to do, and  happiest doing.
Guenevere overhears. She approaches and Lancelot jumps to his feet.
(to Arthur) He must stay for the feasting days  of our wedding, and tell his deeds  himself.
(to Lancelot, smiling) I grant you your wish if you grant  Lady Guenevere hers.
I will stay Madame.
Merlin leans close to Arthur.
The knights of Galys approach the  camp. It would be politic...
...to ride out and meet them.
He rises. Lancelot, who was about to sit again, straighte
I will ride with Sir Kay. Lancelot,  rest here.
Don't start a war on my wedding day!
Without Lancelot?!
Arthur and Merlin exit, leaving Guenevere and Lancelot. S looks at him, lively and amused, and he can't help smilin
Look Lancelot. The maids and ladies  whisper about you. They all dream of  winning you, young and old, fair and  ugly.
Lancelot blushes.
But surely that's no secret to you,  dear Lancelot. You're the bravest  and strongest knight they've ever  seen, and beauty has kissed your  brow.
He can't look at her.
The well-kept secret is whether any  of them has won your heart.
No.
Why?
I am a fighting man and I am married  to the quest. That is enough.
And there is no maiden in the whole  world who inspires you?
There is one.
Who?!
You.
Me?
Yes. I would swear my love to you.
To me? But why?
I cannot love as a woman the lady  who will be wife to my King and my  friend. And, in pledging my love to  you, I cannot love any other woman.
Guenevere smiles, moved by his blunt innocence.
I will see you in all women, and I  will defend them as I would defend  you.
He kneels, kisses her thigh, rises and leaves.

A chorus of children sings. The Bishop waits at the altar with his friars and altar boys. Cornucopias overflowing w vegetables and wildflowers adorn the church, which glows  with the light of a thousand candles. Sir Kay is satisfie He comes back up the petal-strewn aisle.

location: CHAPEL, SITE OF THE SWORD IN THE STONE

text: Arthur and Guenevere are ushered in by Kay. They are flan by Leondegrance and Sir Ector. Lancelot and Merlin follow leading the cortege of knights and ladies. Merlin is incapable of entering the chapel, as if at the  threshold there is an unseen force that repels him.
Lord Merlin, are you ill?
No, no, I need air.

Strangling a laugh he wrenches himself away. Just then Ur and a small party of knights rides up through the tents a dismounts in front of the church. Uryens helps a lady off her horse and joins the cortege on foot.
Merlin, don't you join the  celebration?

Merlin, who was slinking away through the throng of  bystanders, looks up. What he sees sends a chill through body. At Uryens' side stands a young woman of sinister beauty,  with bewitching eyes of ice. Merlin just stares at her, a she smiles back at him faintly.
My wife, Merlin. Lady Morgana of  Cornwall.
I remember you, Merlin. I was a child.  You took my brother away.
Merlin laughs. Uryens shrugs and continues into the chape with Morgana. As she enters she glances back, and just th Merlin steals a look, their eyes meet.

Uryens and Morgana take their places near the altar. Arth and Guenevere kneel before the Bishop, and Arthur takes h hand. The clatter of armor mingles with the enthusiastic, happy singing of the children, and seems to strengthen th song.

location: SITE OF THE SWORD IN THE STONE

text: The chorus carries across the field to the dark wall of t from which issues another chorus, of hoots and squawks an howls. Merlin advances along the edge of the forest. He s by the stone that once held the sword, his eyes wild. He  forgets his inner torment when he sees a plant at the bas of the stone. He kneels beside it and plucks it. He admir its strange flowers; he smells them. Two feet appear at his side. He rises to be face to face  with Morgana. They look deep into each other. Then Merlin breaks the silence.
You left your husband's side? You  left your brother's wedding?
Is that Mandrake, Lord Merlin?
It is.
Can it truly be used for magic?
Merlin smiles at last, and Morgana does, her eyes piercin cruel and lovely.
Yes... sometimes...
His gaze drifts toward the chapel.
...There are many powers in this  world.

Arthur and Guenevere are radiant with joy, and Lancelot b them mirrors the ceremony of their joining in his armor; the sweet voices of the children fill the chapel as the B pours the wine into the chalice, and lifts it up before h blessing it. He turns to the royal couple.
Drink this the blood of Jesus Christ  our Lord.
The chalice seems to burn with a mystical light; and as t chorus soars:
"And Arthur built his castle, Camelot. And one day, in th far reaches of the Kingdom..."

It is shadowy and dark; ancient trees creak, unseen anima cry out. A rabbit hops into view and a boy leaps forward, grabbing the animal by the ears before it can move. He-- Perceval--is a wild boy of seventeen, dressed in skins wi an endearing and childlike smile.
(to the rabbit) Sorry. Hungry.

A din is heard to the forest, and it grows. Perceval glan around, panicked. The sound is the rubbing of leather upo leather, of metal on metal, for now a mounted figure in a hovers over the terrified boy.
(stuttering) Have I taken too much?
He lets the rabbit go free. The threatening figure dismou And Perceval, cartwheels backward, landing in the stream scooping a fish out.
(desperately trying  to ingratiate) I had rabbit yesterday. Today I'll  eat fish... No?
He returns the fish to the water. The figure steps into a pool of sunlight and a glorious halo streaks from the arm It is Lancelot.
Don't be afraid.
Perceval is overcome with astonishment, and he kneels.
You're an angel! Not a devil...
Lancelot laughs and pulls the boy to his feet.
Just a man. A knight in the King's  service.
You're a man?! (he reaches out to  touch Lancelot) ...with metal skin!
Perceval is beside himself with enthusiasm.
Can I grow metal skin?
Lancelot rolls his eyes, amused.
You've got a lot to learn.
Lancelot is cantering and Perceval is running alongside,  shouting in gasps.
I'll learn... take me... to the  King... What's a... King?
Lancelot shakes his head and spurs the horse into a gallo Perceval lengthens his stride, and keeps up! Lancelot rei to a halt.
Very well. Climb up.
I will run.
Listen, boy, it's more than twenty  days from here.
Twenty days!? The world is that big?

Perceval cannot believe his eyes. As Lancelot and Kay tal about him out of earshot, he sees things that he's never  seen before; and he gapes like the country bumpkin that h is. Dragon-like kites sweep low, maneuvered by children. In a meadow among the trees, knights hone their skills with la and sword, and ladies watch and their "bright eyes rain  influence and judge the prize." And then, there is Camelo itself; the great gate and the drawbridge; the massive wa and the soaring towers and spires above. Perceval rushes up to Lancelot and Kay.
Who will give me my sword?
Kay is not at all pleased; nonetheless he takes the boy b the ear and leads him across the drawbridge and into the  castle.
Kitchen knives and greasy spits will  be your weapons, boy.

Lancelot smiles to himself, hesitation, lingering before great gate of Camelot. There is a walkway suspended in the trees above, that als leads to the castle, and promenading on it is a group of  women, Guenevere and her ladies-in-waiting. The Queen see Lancelot and hastens toward him. Lancelot sees her, and mounts his horse and heads back in the forest. She stops, somewhat ahead of the ladies, and  watches wistfully. Lancelot turns back and seeing her one last time, draws d his visor and spurs his horse into a canter. He passes two commoners who are heading for the castle, o fat and the other thin, and they are locked in hot disput Their wives keep them from coming to blows and their chil spur them on, enjoying the excitement. Lancelot is swallowed by the forest.

location: HALL OF THE ROUND TABLE, CAMELOT

text: Guenevere, bearing a bowl of perfect, deep red apples,  approaches the Round Table, where Arthur sits and Merlin his side, attending to the affairs of the kingdom. Quite few of the knights occupy their seats, talking with each  other, drinking and laughing, attended by ladies and page Guenevere places the apples at Lancelot's empty place and takes her seat next to Arthur. In the archways that lead into the hall, petitioners wait eating, drinking, talking among themselves. In the din, n one pays attention to the vehement arguing of the fat man and the thin man, which continues even here. The hall is burgeoning, happy center of the kingdom. But Merlin is oblivious to the lively clamor. He gazes li a lovesick puppy across the table at Morgana, who bends o whispering to a knight at the table, the young Sir Gahalt while his older brother Sir Gawain listens. Morgana notic Merlin's stare and smiles at him, and then resumes her  flirtation with Sir Gahalt, much to Merlin's annoyance. Sir Kay ushers the thin man and the fat man into the open space at the center of the table for their audience with king. They quarrel even as Kay tries to present them, and the attention of the hall gradually focuses on them. The two men talk at once, interrupting, overlapping. FAT MAN

I brew ale, sir--from  old shoes--I am an  honest tradesman sir.  I must sell what I  produce. He won't buy  ale and he won't pay.  Pay up! He leans over  the barrel and sucks  in the vapors. The  vapors are mine.
Arthur is both amused and exasperated.
Enough!... What is a fair price for  the smell of your ale?
That's why we have come to you, sir  There's no one else who can tell us.
What does it cost to get drunk on  your ale?
At least three shillings, sir.
Arthur addresses the Thin Man.
Give me three shillings.

The Thin Man is crestfallen, the smile gone from his face He reluctantly hands the coins to Kay, who gives them to  Arthur. Arthur tosses them in the air and lets them fall a metal plate. He hands them back to the Thin Man, who is totally confused now, as is everybody else.
For the smell of your ale, the jingle  of his coins.
The knights roar with laughter and the Fat Man and the Th Man look at each other in astonishment. Perceval lets out raucous laugh that wins him a glance of disapproval from  Kay.

The din of the petitioners is replaced by music. It is th hour of the evening feast, and all knights are present, e Lancelot. Whole tree trunks burn in the great fireplace, lambs roast on spits in the flames. Pages run to and fro  with trays of food and wine, Perceval among them. Morgana stops beside Merlin.
What did I see today in the wizard's  eyes? Censure, because I enjoy a few  words with a young handsome knight?
Merlin is in agony, a bug stuck on a pin.
No, no, of course not. You are  young...
I'm not jealous!
It's clear you are, and it irks me.
No. Yes, I am. I am jealous. I want  to write poems about you with  moonbeams, make the sea sing your  name...
A lovestruck page!
Shh... yes, yes. Sit with me,  please... Morgana.
She does, laughing and in complete control. His hand  immediately slides onto her thigh. She removes it, but ho it in her hand, toying with his fingers.
A steamy, panting, lovestruck page.  But what good are songs and poems to  me? They are the barter of ordinary  love. A gift that reflected your  greatness is the only one worthy of  your love.
Merlin looks at her, knowing already, sad yet eager.
I showed you all my conjuring  tricks...
The deepest secrets, the forbidden  formulas...
Maybe... maybe...
Merlin's thoughts have carried him far away, when he real that Arthur is addressing him.
Merlin, are you counselor to the  King, or to my sister?
Some knights laugh.
At your service, sir.

Then answer me this. For years peace  has reigned in the land. Crops grow  in abundance, there is no want. Every  one of my subjects enjoys his portion  of happiness and justice, even those  whose tiresome misunderstandings we  must resolve here each day. Tell me,  Merlin: have we defeated evil, as it  seems?
Good and evil; there is never one  without the other.
Arthur is taken aback.
Where hides evil, then, in my kingdom?
Never where you expect it, that's  all I know.
He chuckles softly and Arthur is puzzled. A knight speaks out, the young knight with whom Morgana was flirting. His manner is sarcastic.
If we have peace and justice, why is  Lancelot never with us? Why is he  always riding out on his quests? He  must know where this evil is.
Could there be evil within Lancelot  himself? To live above human folly,  as is his aim, is to be overly proud.
He pays no heed even to the Queens  longing for his company.
The hall falls silent, all eyes upon the Queen.
(lashing out) What is it you would have your words  mean, Sir Gahalt?
Frightened, Gahalt doesn't answer. Morgana has slipped to Guenevere's side.
Don't listen to him. You are the  Queen.
Arthur, ashen-faced, turns to Merlin for help, but he has escaped into sleep...
Sir Gahalt, answer the Queen.

No. I meant not to be angry with  you, Sir Gahalt. In the idleness  that comes with peace gossip has  bread its own evil. You merely repeat  it. Please, sir, have one of those  apples that Lancelot loves, and in  that gesture partake of its goodness.

Morgana picks the bowl up and as she does so, unseen by a and with a magician's dexterity, she thrusts her fingerna deep into the top apple. She gives the bowl to Guenevere, who takes it and sweeps around to where Sir Gahalt sits,  followed by Morgana. The young knight jumps to his feet.
Take one, Sir Gahalt.
I am most honored, my lady.

He is too shy to take the shiniest, most beautiful apple top, and goes for another one. Morgana giggles, and he lo at her. She looks at the apple on top and then smiles  encouragingly at him. Sir Gahalt takes it and starts eati as the Queen returns to her seat. With the third bite his is unable to breathe. His face go red and he rises to his feet, attempting to call out. He falls, dying immediately. All leap to their feet, and  Arthur rushes to the young knight. Merlin is asleep and f from human affairs. Arthur and Sir Gawain rise from the body of the young kni Sir Gawain backs away from Arthur and points at Guenevere trembling with cold rage.
Hear me, Lord Arthur, and knights  and chieftains: I charge Guenevere  with the murder of my brother.
Guenevere, white and with a broken voice, turns to Arthur
I didn't... I am innocent.
She begins to swoon and Morgana keeps her steady on her f Arthur slumps into his seat and Sir Gawain kneels before  him.
I champion this truth: That Queen  Guenevere murdered Sir Gahalt with  the aid of sorcery.
Enraged, Arthur reaches for Excalibur. But with effort he checks his impulse.
The Queen will be in my charge till  a champion steps forward to fight on  her behalf.
Not you, my husband?
Arthur cannot look at her.
She must be burnt at the stake. That  is the sentence for murder done with  magic.
It is. Lords and knights of the Round  Table, as her husband I say that  this deed was not done by Guenevere.  Who among you will champion this  truth?
No one responds. Guenevere falls into her seat. Arthur  searches the eyes of his knights and they evade him.
Sir Caradoc! You!
The knight looks up.
I am torn.
Sir Ector, old and feeble, weeps for Arthur. Someone spea up. It is Perceval, who kneels before the Queen. His voic is unnaturally loud, and his eyes shine with held-back te he stutters.
I will champion you, my lady.
He is overwhelmed by his own boldness. He looks around. A eyes are upon him. Guenevere smiles at him, sadly.
I thank you, but you are not yet a  knight.
I will find Lancelot! He will come!
Perceval hurries from the hall. Arthur looks away, ashame and his eyes fall on Merlin, twitching and mumbling in hi sleep.
Boys!... boys will be boys...

In full armor but for his helmet, Lancelot is seated at a small table in the shadow of a tree, eating an apple. A young girl is turning a chicken on a spit, and her moth is removing freshly-baked bread from an oven. It is very  peaceful and silent until, galloping all out, Perceval  arrives. Frantic, out of breath, he leaps from his lather horse.
I have found you. The Queen. An apple. Tomorrow. Sir Gawain...
--It must wait, child. These good  ladies, for whom I intervened once,  will honor me with a meal. I am  beholden to them now as I was when  they begged my protection.
The two women set the chicken and the bread before the gr knight, and stand back to watch him eat, flushed with  excitement. Perceval falls silent, in awe of Lancelot.
Arthur stands hunched over the fireplace, staring into th flames. Guenevere paces back and forth to a window.
Why can't you be my champion?
If I am your judge, I cannot be your  champion. When I act as your King, I  cannot be your husband.
And you cannot love me...
The laws, my laws, must bind everyone,  high and low, or they are not laws  at all. Lancelot will come...
And if he cannot be found, no other  knight will champion me, though you  beseeched each and every one of them.  Why be king if there is no one you  can call loyal subject but an eager  boy?
He hides his anguish from her. Numb with hurt, she goes t tall curtained window, and draws it open, and stands ther looking out upon the surrounding forest, silent and still beneath the moon.

She cries softly, and she whispers the name of the great  knight. EXT. EDGE OF THE FOREST, WALLS OF CAMELOT - NIGHT. A mounted knight stands motionless at the edge of the for his armor gleaming with dark lustre. It is Lancelot. His  eyes are raised to the high window, where he sees Gueneve He watches her in silence. In the high window Guenevere d the curtain and Lancelot reins back into the forest.

Lancelot has unsaddled and tethered his horse in a small  clearing. He sits, resting back against a tree. He remove his helmet; he plants his sword before him, like a cross. loosens the ties of his breastplate. He waits for day,  yawning, tired. But his eyes burn, and he closes them and nods off to sleep. A knight appears silently hovering over him. Lancelot loo up, and his eyes go wide with fear. The knight towering a him wears armor identical to his, and he raises his sword and the blade is descending upon Lancelot. Lancelot draws his sword from the ground and rolls away, but the knight' sword slices through his shoulder joint. Lancelot attempt to rise but already the knight, Lancelot's mirror image, upon him.
