From the ground, Lancelot parries the blow and  slashes at the opponent's knee, cutting through the joint the armor and severing the leg. The knight doesn't fall, doesn't bleed, doesn't cry out. one leg he comes forward, a horror. Lancelot is paralyzed fear. As the knight leaps upon Lancelot, Lancelot rises t meet him, impaling himself on the knight's sword below th hauberk. He throws the knight to the ground, and comes do upon him. He rips off the helmet and the breastplate. The armor is empty and Lancelot rolls over on his back, awake from the nightmare with his own sword deep in his stomach and in his hand his own helmet and breastplate, while oth parts of his armor lie strewn around him. Only then does he become conscious of the terrible pain a the shock of the truth. He grabs the hilt of his sword an draws it from his stomach. He curls up in agony, clutchin fistful of leaves to the wound.
Guenevere, I fight against myself...
He loses consciousness.

The Bishop blesses the field. Guenevere, numb and  disbelieving, is being led to the stake, which rises from bed of straw and wood. Arthur watches, in shock. Other kn and ladies keep their distance, watching darkly, stealing glances at Arthur, mumbling disapproval of his refusing t defend Guenevere. In battle dress, Sir Gawain rides up an down the jousting run on a snorting and powerful horse,  practicing. Perceval, in a mail doublet, waits beside a m roan, his face burning with anxiety. Guenevere is tied to the stake. All eyes watch for the  approach of her champion. Arthur goes to Perceval.
Is he coming?
He heard Lady Guenevere's request  and he said nothing. That is all.
Arthur hides his pain behind a rigid mask.
The sun has risen shining cruelly into Guenevere's eyes; queen is alone at the stake. Sir Gawain rides up to King  Arthur, who waits alone, separated from the others.
My Lord, the sun is upon the field.  The Queen has no champion. I demand  justice, as is my right.
So it is.
Perceval leaps onto his horse.
Let me champion the Queen!
Sir Gawain looks at the squire with contempt.
(to Arthur) Since no knight comes forward, I  demand justice--
Arthur is in anguish. He searches the tree line for a sig of Lancelot. He looks from Guenevere at the stake to his knights watching him. He draws Excalibur. A gasp goes thr the crowd of onlookers.
Boy, kneel.
Perceval leaps from his horse and bends his knee before t King. Arthur brings the sword down on the boy's shoulder, giving him the three strokes.
In the name of God, of St. Michael,  and St. George, I make you a knight.  Rise, Sir...
...Perceval!

Gawain shakes his head disdainfully as Perceval mounts ba into the saddle, his eyes burning with fervor. Sir Gawain and Perceval ride to opposite ends of the fiel The spectators fall silent, all staring blankly, their se dulled by the tragedy, at the uneven combatants. A cry goes up. Lancelot rides out of the forest. He rides to the King and salutes him. Arthur smiles at his old fri tears of joy in his eyes. Lancelot bows toward Guenevere rides on to where Perceval waits. Lancelot reaches out to touch Perceval's cheek.
It's my task to prove the Queen's  innocence.

Perceval cannot reply, his eyes affixed on the blood that trickles from Lancelot's hauberk. Lancelot raises his lan in salute to Gawain across the field. Gawain salutes in  answer. The two huge knights charge at each other, each man's spe tip making contact with the other's armor, and in the vio collision both are unhorsed. Lancelot is slower at gettin to his feet and drawing his sword. He is bleeding below the hauberk from his self-inflicted  wound. In the first onslaught Lancelot fights defensively, falli back. He has to toss aside his shield and hold his stomac with his shield hand. Morgana watches with Merlin. Every terrible blow of sword sword reverberates through her body pleasurable. Merlin i captivated by her cruel sensuality.

They swing and thrust at each other with slower but bone- crushing force, both unsteady now. Blood seeps from Lance feet, leaving awful footprints on the earth. Finally, wit daring thrust, Lancelot lifts Gawain's visor and the swor tip is before his eyes. Gawain drops his sword and shield kneels and speaks in a voice hoarse with weariness.
The Queen is innocent. I yield to  your mercy, Sir Lancelot.
Lancelot collapses in a dead faint.

Eyes closed, Lancelot lies on a bed, naked but for a clot across his loins. His minor wounds have been dressed, and Merlin is kneading the huge gash in his stomach, working severed flesh together. Guenevere stands on one side of t bed, Arthur on the other, both looking down upon Lancelot relieved and not daring to look at each other.
Flesh on flesh. You must press on  the wound, Guenevere, hold it, and  it will begin to bind.
Guenevere kneels, and at her touch Lancelot's eyes flicke open. Merlin exits, and draws Arthur away with him. Arthur is deeply tormented.
Merlin, tell me. Now that Guenevere  is returned to me...
What is it my child?
Merlin appears moved by the predicaments that Arthur has face.
Will I have a son?
Merlin stares off into the evening sky, where a lark sing high up.
Yes.
Just yes? No mad laughter, no riddles,  nothing but a simple yes? That  frightens me.

A king should be afraid, always. The  enemy is everywhere. Waiting in ambush  in the dark corridors of his castle,  on the deer paths of his forest, or  in the gray and winding paths of a  more tangled forest, in here.
He taps his skull and smiles.

Lancelot is staring into Guenevere's eyes. She opens her  shift, baring a breast with the innocence of a mother  preparing to suckle a child. She presses her breast to hi wound, her face to his chest, her arms enfolding him. She whispers.
Flesh on flesh. I will heal you.
His body trembles and his eyes brim with tears. He is los

location: HALL OF THE ROUND TABLE, CAMELOT

text: The court is assembled, for the evening feast. There is m and heavy drinking. Some knights are slouched across the  table. Lancelot, still weak, takes his seat, looking at t drunken and frivolous knights. Arthur catches it, and the smile at each other.
They miss the battlefield. I think  we do too.
But one can still keep a sword sharp  riding out in the name of the King's  law.
Guenevere cannot tear her eyes from Lancelot. He avoids h look. Arthur looks from Guenevere to Lancelot, and speaks softly to him, across her, and with stabbing directness.
It is not easy for the young ones to  learn knightly virtues without the  hard teaching of war and quest. It  is only your example, Lancelot, that  binds them now.
Then, addressing the hall:
Which is the greatest quality of  knighthood? Courage? Compassion?  Loyalty? Humility? What do you say,  Merlin?
He is bent close to Morgana, whispering. Only when the ha rings with laughter does he look up.
What? (then seeing he has  an audience) The greatest? They blend together  like the metals we mix to make a  good sword.
I didn't ask for poetry. Which is  it?
Merlin looks from Arthur to Guenevere to Lancelot to Arth
All right. Truth. It must be truth,  above all. When a man lies he murders  some part of the world.
An uneasy silence falls upon the feast. Guenevere and Lan cannot look at each other, and Arthur feels it. Lancelot  jumps to his feet.
Conversation and court life don't  suit me. I must take my rest in the  forest.
Guenevere stifles her dismay.
Hasn't Merlin mended your wound?
It is deep...
Arthur is about to rise to embrace him, but checks himsel
You will be sorely missed. Heal  yourself and come back.
The exchange has become closely intimate, even though the stand apart and speak before everyone in the large hall.  Lancelot leaves. Only Guenevere cannot watch.

Water gurgles from a rock that is captive in the roots of ancient oak. Lancelot, in armor, reclines against its tru the roots cradling him. He is perfectly still, drawing li from the vibrant, all-enfolding forest. Flower petals drift on the breeze. Trees sigh. Fox and ra sparrow and hawk, at peace with each other, watch over th knight.
A horse and rider tear through the thick undergrowth. It Guenevere. The forest races past her as she gallops towar the glade, brambles tearing at her flesh and clothes.
Lancelot gets to his feet, tense. Guenevere dismounts and approaches. She is flushed and breathless from the wild r Her horse, left free, wanders over to his and grazes besi it.
Why? You will destroy Arthur, and  us...
She moves closer and he thrusts out his mailed fist to ke her away. She clutches it and presses the metal to her so tear-streaked cheek.
The law forbids it.
Love demands it.
Hungry with passion, she embraces the cold unmoving armor kissing it.
There are things about love--
--Nothing!
He steps back, drawing his sword. He holds it up by the b between them.
By my knight's sword, I swore faith--

And before he can finish she grabs the blade to push it a He holds it fast. Blood streams from her bare hands. He c prevail without cutting them deeply. He lets go of the sw and she lets it fall to the ground. She embraces his still and defeated hulk. She kisses the  metal, and sensation shoots through him, dizzying him.
Guenevere...
He folds her in his arm, and their bodies lock together a though a trap had sprung. Their mouths meet, each devouri the other...
Arthur and Merlin, the King desperate, the Wizard overwhe by compassion:

I am alone and betrayed. By my wife,  by my beloved friend, by my knights.  And by you. Perhaps most of all by  you. For you made me, you forged  this wretched life. And like a child  tired of a toy, you toss me aside, a  babbling lecher trotting after my  sister...
That is my destiny. I have a destiny,  too...
With all your powers, you are content  to be ridiculed, laughed at...

My powers fade, Arthur. I resort to  cheap tricks... (with sudden enthusiasm) Yes! I enjoy every moment of my  foolishness, I join in the making of  it, so no one can betray me. But  you! You betray yourself.
Me? I have lived by the oath of king  and knight.
You betray the boy who drew the sword,  the boy who saw the Dragon... the  Dragon who moves close by, coiling  and uncoiling, restless, looking  down, waiting for the King to be a  king...
Arthur looks up and in the rolling clouds maybe, just may the form of a dragon is taking shape. Arthur draws Excali intensity animating his dead features.
I must do it myself. I must kill  them both. Lancelot and Guenevere.  Will you ride with me, Merlin?
I cannot. I must not. Here I must  stay.

They embrace. Merlin is on the verge of tears, his face  immediately sad and finally ancient. Arthur exits. Morgana, who has been watching from the shadows, watching from the shadows, slinks up to Merlin's side.
Crazy old fool. You think yourself a  kingmaker. Ha! A meddler, more likely.  Look what a mess you've made of  things.
Merlin smiles knowingly at her.

I? Perhaps, perhaps. I'm losing  interest, Morgana... I have helped  men--or meddled in their affairs, if  you would have it that way--since  the dawn of time. Now let them live  by their own laws. Let them stand on  their own feet. The gods of once are  gone forever, it is time for men...  Morgana, make a man out of me. Kiss  me.
He reaches to touch her lips. She cradles his hand in her and doesn't allow Merlin to kiss her. She kisses his knuc and stares into his eyes, stoking his desire.
You know what I want. I want the  secret of true magic, how to thicken  the stuff of dreams and wishes with  the flesh of the world.
That I cannot.
She breaks away, provocative, alluring.
Then I will not.
Arthur and Sir Kay gallop through the forest, silently. I is not a dream.  Their armor and the hooves of their hors are muffled with pieces of cloth.

Only Nature will ever see their love; the creatures of th air, tree and ground witness the final reality of their  passion and sense its unfathomable depths, singing of it a hundred languages. Lancelot and Guenevere are naked and interlocked, one being, suspended in the darkness in the of the forest.
Arthur walks soundlessly through the trees, approaching t glade. The forest falls suddenly silent.

All passion spent, locked in each other's arms, Lancelot Guenevere drift off into sleep. Arthur comes upon them. He stands over them. He draws  Excalibur. Checking all emotion, he holds it above his he The ancient steel glows darkly. The lovers faces are serene and innocently beautiful. He  hesitates, tormented. His mask of anguish gives way to  determination and calm. He strikes the sword home, lettin go of it. He backs away, turns and disappears into the forest.

The sky is red; so is the steel of Excalibur. Lancelot aw and starts at what he sees. His cry stirs Guenevere. They are horrified to see Excalibur impaled in the ground betw their entwined bodies. It has pierced their union without grazing their flesh. They leap up and back away, unable t speak at first.
Why didn't he kill us?
He has given up.
She kneels before the sword, embracing the hilt to her br
The King without his sword, the land  without a king...
We are to blame.

Lancelot stumbles into the forest, berserk with guilt. He rages against a small tree, crying out, and he rips its r from the ground, the terrible tearing and renting the sym of his own inner torment. Guenevere sinks to the ground next to Lancelot's empty ar and his abandoned sword.
Merlin and Morgana descend winding steps cut out of rock. The only light comes from the glow of Merlin's staff.
When Arthur built the castle, I carved  out a place for myself, where I could  laugh or sleep, and no one would  bother me.
People make you laugh?
He laughs.
They do.
Why?
He leans close to her ear, whispering into it.
They don't know how close they live  to the edge of delight or disas...
He is about to kiss her when he slips. He laughs.
Happiness or horror.

They pass through jaws of stalactites and stalagmites. Me cracks his staff whip-like and a ball of fire billows up  from the tip and illuminates a cave wildly veined and  filigreed with minerals and crusted with growths of cryst The light goes out but the malachite and the gold, the qu diamond and beryllium burn dully. He turns to her, sudden tall and unstooped, younger, sleek and evil.

In the folds of the earth where the  forces that hold the world together  are more alive, my power is strongest.  Here I will possess you, as a man  possesses a woman. And the god, the  eunuch, the mule that I was, will be  no more.
He sweeps her up into his arms.
You are truly magnificent!

Flattery! Do you think I am ignorant  of your stupid little games? Preying  on you weakness of others. That's  your power, a petty evil. Mine is  great. Great plans. Impossible dreams.  Laughable endings...
He deposits her on bare rock. He kisses her. She pushes h away.
Merlin, the powers of Summoning, the  true Name of the charms of Doing and  Undoing. Show me!
I won't. You would misuse such power.  I have paid enough for you, and I  will have you.
She leans forward and kisses his ear and whispers.
Make magic, my foolish wizard. For  our love. Weave a marvelous room  around us, a room worthy of our  coupling.
She draws closer, kissing him deeply. He breathes heavily
What do you want? You must desire it  for me to weave it.
Walls of shining crystals, burning  with red fire, furnishings of metals  and jewels never seen by man...
Morgana falls silent as Merlin raises a hand, majesticall intoning a harsh repetitive charm. The mineral veins of t cave begin to glow and fog seeps out from them enveloping the couple.
Desire it and it will be as you  desire.

Morgana burns with intensity. Merlin utters a formula and the fog coalesces around them into the shimmering presenc of crystal walls, fountains raining jewels, flowers made scented air, a bed of glass shot with light and covered w skins of animals dead before the time of man, goblets of  ruby, tapestries woven of golden hair. She reaches out to touch the wall and her hand plunges through the unmateria illusion.
It's only a semblance. You disappoint  me.
She begins lacing up her loosened gown.
Don't touch the walls. Come close to  me.
She does, a mad hope in her eyes. She kisses his chest.
Do it, Merlin, the deepest secret.  Fix it with the charm of Making, for  our endless pleasure.
He utters the ancient charm, Morgana listening closely,  memorizing it. The illusion is all of a sudden solid.
For you...

She runs her hand across the hard crystal surface, her ey gleaming. From outside the wondrous room they can be seen to embrac He carries her to the magical bed where he makes love to  her, as they disappear from view in its effulgent light. She comes out through the crystal door, burning with evil intent. She turns to watch him asleep in the bed. She utters the charm of Summoning learnt from Merlin, and the room melts into an eddying carmine fog. Within it, Me struggles to awaken from the torpor of love, alarmed. Outside, Morgana utters the charm of Making and the gaseo mass begins to crystallize. Inside, Merlin is rising to his feet, breathing the red f his movements slowing to a standstill, his mouth opening a scream of horror. The cloud has metamorphosed into a magnificent cluster of red crystals.  Morgana peers into its facets and there sh sees, in fragments, Merlin's terror... an eye, the gaping mouth, a clawing hand--as he is entombed in the stone. Sh laughs in triumph.
Surrounded by forest, the spires and battlements of Camel rise under black storm clouds. Arthur and Kay ride back t the castle.
The great hall is in gloom. Few knights are in attendance the table. Some sleep off last night's wine. Arthur approaches, hagg searching.
Has no one seen Merlin?
Knights look up; those who meet Arthur's reddened eyes sh their heads. Arthur leaves. A knight whispers to another.
Did you see? The King was without  Excalibur...

Echoing in the vaulted corridors outside the hall, the  knight's whisper stabs Arthur. The words now seem borne on the whistling wind and follow the King wherever he goes in search of Merlin. He comes u a knight seducing a lady in a dark corner by the chapel d his hand under her gown. Arthur notes the sacrilege in  silence, and continues on his way.

The wind keens. Thunder rolls overhead. Arthur enters his bedchamber. He sits by the empty fireplace, a broken man. Feminine hands light on his shoulders. He starts. He look up. It is Morgana. He smiles and grasps her hand.
I'll weep for you, brother, for a  King must not weep.
She comes around and she kneels in front of him. Before h can talk she silences him with a tender caress.
Do you know what Guenevere's maids  have whispered?
He shakes his head.
That when the King returned from  battle...
She begins untying the laces of his metal thigh and shin  guards.
...Guenevere would unlace his armor  and massage the burns where metal  rubbed on flesh...
She is stripping his legs naked, gently touching the fles with her fingertips. He stares off, remembering.
...She would prepare a bath for you,  mixing special ointment in the  water...

Arthur's eyes brim with tears. Morgana weeps, embracing h knees. He rests his hand gently upon her head, choked wit remembrance, soothing her. But as she weeps, she incants charm. Arthur looks down upon her, and the woman who looks up at him is Guenevere, a Guenevere with cold ice eyes. He is m weak by desire and weakened further by magic. He holds he face adoringly.
Guenevere! You are--

--Don't speak. A thousand words, a  hundred thousand words, would only  be prologue to the truth that must  be. That you, King, and I, your Queen,  beget a son to bond our love and to  strengthen our weak kingdom with a  successor. Come, my lord...

She draws him to the floor and upon her body, holding him tightly to himself. Arthur trembles with excitement, path in his desperate passion. As he takes her, she shudders, losing control of the char and her features change till once again "Guenevere" is  Morgana. She holds him in a tight embrace so that he may see her. She whispers in his ear.
The moon flows in my blood to meet  your seed. And already I bear him  who will be King.
Arthur wrenches himself away so he can see her, her arms  still around his neck. He looks down upon her, aghast,  incredulous.
I could easily kill you, brother.  But I want you to live to see our  son be King. In me, the blood of  Cornwall will have its revenge; in  me, the blood of Uther will show its  dark side.
She presses her thumbs into his neck and he faints.
Morgana, with a small party, rides away from the castle  through the lashing storm, till they are taken from sight the folds of the forest...

Lightening forks across the sky, illuminating the interio The chapel has been transformed into a place of satanic  worship. Held up and surrounded by hooded figures, Morgan lies on the altar, her pregnant belly huge; and her featu are fierce with passionate intensity. She writhes in the  pangs of childbirth.
Stand back, all of you. Through my  own body I have nurtured him with my  potions. I made him. I alone can  give him life.

Arthur enters, pale and haunted. Mass is being celebrated and some knights are present. Those not asleep whisper to each other about the King. The sound of an approaching st is heard. As the priest raises the chalice to consecrate the wine.  Arthur comes down the aisle and steps onto the altar. He  reaches out to grasp the chalice from the priest's hands.

Morgana holds aloft her beautiful newborn baby, his body  glistening in a flash of lightening. She is triumphant. INT. CHAPEL, CAMELOT - NIGHT. A bolt of lightening strikes the chalice, rocking the cha and Arthur is knocked back violently. Rain lashes in through the shattered window upon the terr knights. They and the priest back away. Arthur is left al He rises and goes to the chalice, which is bent and crack He kneels before it. Steam hisses up as rain falls on it.

Sun streams in. Many of the knights are in attendance, in full armor. Ladies and pages watch from dark corners. Arthur addresse the fellowship. He holds the cracked chalice in his hands. He burns with new-found fervor.

Who will ride the labyrinths of the  forest, to the very root of his soul,  to the very ends of the earth, to  find the secret that will redeem us  from the evil that has fallen upon  us, and make this chalice, and  ourselves, whole again?
Gawain rises and draws his sword in salute.
I will ride forth in the name of  that quest, and commit my strength  and my soul to it.
Perceval, Kay and a few others draw their swords and touc their lips to the blades in oath. Sunbeams splash off the armor.
I will go.
The rest of the fellowship draw their swords in imitation but the resolution within them is not strong. Arthur come forward to Gawain.
Gawain, a dreadful fear is upon me,  that we may never meet again, that  the fellowship will be no more...
He embraces Gawain, tears in his eyes. He turns to Percev and Perceval kneels.
We will find the secret or die.
Arthur kisses the young knight's brow. Then he turns to K
Kay, I know your heart yearns to go,  but I am prisoner to my duties, and  you must be to yours, at my side.
Arthur and Kay watch the knights file out till the hall i empty, the harsh song of their armor growing distant.
"For nine years they searched. Morgana's power grew in th land."

Under a leaden sky, Gawain drives his horse through swirl snow. He comes upon a mounted knight who is frozen in his tracks. He brushes the snow from the man's face. The froz features belong to Caradoc. He slowly continues on his wa

Dangling from the branches of a dead tree are a dozen dea knights of the Round Table, crows pecking at the rotting  flesh in the chinks of armor. Perceval rides up, cries ou in horror, and spurs his horse away.
The rotting carcasses of sheep. The crops blackened and  withered on the stalk. Hungry peasants head for a distant hill.

A giant head has been carved out of an outcrop of rock, i stone mouth gaping toward the sky. People are congregated around the mouth. Peasants and far they are wild with excitement, responding to drums throbb and bagpipes wailing. They watch Morgana, who is surrounded by knights in dark  armor. At her side is an angelic boy of eight, his eyes c as his mother's. Morgana is more beautiful than ever, in  flowing druidic robes, the gossamer silk clinging to her  sweat-drenched body. She is standing by the deep hole which forms the giant's  open mouth. It is covered by a tooth-like grating acting a drain for the blood of human sacrifices made there. Bef her is Gawain, chained and struggling against five strong men who hold him. Morgana lifts a dagger and plunges it i Gawain's chest. The fountain of blood that gushes from th great knight's body drives the crowd into a frenzy.

(intoning) The blood of this knight will feed  the god in the earth, he is weak  with hunger, and he will be made  strong by this blood. Then he will  plant his seed, and the land will be  fertile once again.
Gawain, his blood flowing from him and into the giant's m looks up in anguish. His bellowing voice is echoed and  amplified by the hollow beneath the drain.
Arthur, forgive me. I die without  the secret. I have failed.
Gawain's death cry and the din of the ritual carries to  Perceval's ears as he wanders through the wasteland. He d down his visor and spurs his horse forward.

He gallops toward the giant's head. He checks his sword a lowers his lance. The knight charging forward on his war horse is an awesom sight, but the crowd around the giant's mouth is strangel unfrightened. Morgana is excited; she turns to the boy.
Look, Mordred, a true prize for the  giant. The lamb rides into our jaws.
Perceval is galloping toward them when the ground gives w beneath the horse, and he and the animal plunge into a pi The cheering crowd rushes to the edge of the trap.
(to Mordred) You must kill him, for this knight  is dear to your father. You must do  it and learn to enjoy your father's  pain.
Her knights drag Perceval, unarmed, into Morgana's presen
Have you found what you search for?  Have you found what Arthur seeks?
Perceval doesn't answer, defiant and hiding his fear.
You haven't, or you would be smiling  now in the face of death. Your quest  is an impossible one.
That it might be impossible makes it  all the more necessary.
Fool! (to the men holding  Perceval) Uncover him. I'll show you the mystery  of life. It's death... (to Mordred) Do it, Mordred!

Holding Perceval by his limbs and hair, the men force him down on the bloody grating, drawing back his head, exposi his throat. Morgana kneels by his head, and draws the boy beside her. She holds the tip of the dagger to Perceval's neck and takes Mordred's hand and wraps it around the han Perceval is choked with fear, his heart pounding in his  throat.
Feel the life through the dagger,  child. It belongs to you.
The boy looks up at his mother. The vein in Perceval's ne pushes against the dagger's point.
I feel it, Mother. I will give his  blood to the giant.

The boy raises the dagger, and hesitates just a bit. Perc resigns himself bravely. He looks the child calmly in the eye. Mordred brings down the blade without strength, just piercing the skin with the tip. He lets go of the dagger, afraid now of his mistake. The dagger clatters to the grating and slips away down th drain, before Morgana can retrieve it. She rages against  Mordred. In the confusion, Perceval tears loose, the men  holding him slipping on the blood-wet stone. Perceval runs through the crowd. Immediately, lance lower a knight is upon him. Perceval leaps toward him, catching the lance in his hand, and pulling down the rider with it He jumps the rider and draws the knight's sword. Whirling the lance and cutting the air with the sword, he keeps ba the other knights for a moment, giving him time to see hi chance. He leaps onto the riderless horse and charges off through the crowd. He reins in abruptly, the horse rearin He is wary of the ground before him; there could be a hid pit. But there is no time to think. Knights and men on fo are rushing him. He spurs forward into a gallop, the hors striding mightily And its hind leg sinks into a pit, the  animal losing its gait. But the momentum carries the hors forward, and it recovers from the stumble. Perceval gallops away. Morgana is enraged. She shakes Mordred by the hair.
You didn't kill him! You didn't kill  him!
But suddenly she begins kissing him tenderly.
My dear, sweet boy...
He just stands there emotionless, the dead center of her  turbulent passions.

Perceval gallops down a trail. The black-armored knights Morgana chase him. Perceval reins into deep cover alongside the trail. The  pursuers thunder past and the sound of hooves recedes.  Perceval checks his newly found sword, slashes the air to feel the weapon's balance. He re-sheathes it. He pats the horse.
We'll become good friends.

He starts off again, into the patchless forest of dead tr He is suddenly set upon by a wildman who, swinging a smal uprooted tree, knocks him off his horse. Perceval crashes the ground and before he can use his sword the wildman ha knocked it out of his hand. It is Lancelot, demented, who furiously rains battering b on Perceval's armor, bellowing with rage. All that Percev can do is attempt to avoid the blows. Lancelot addresses  Perceval as if the young knight were Lancelot himself.

Where are you going, Lancelot, in  your iron tomb? Still trying to save  the world? (He hammers blows  into Perceval's armor) The best... the bravest... the  greatest... fool that ever lived.  Now the world rots. Death is king of  the earth. And it is you who make it  so, Lancelot.

Before Perceval can speak, Lancelot disappears again into the forest, his eyes blank, as though his encounter with young knight had never happened. A knot of pain, Perceval pulls himself up. He tries to ri into the saddle. He is too hurt to do it. He starts off o foot, slowly, leading the horse.

It is very dark and Perceval has to feel his way. He comes to the edge of a stream. He kneels to drink, and the horse drinks beside him. Then he rests back on his he brooding, too tired to rise. He lowers his eyes, staring into the dark water, defeated empty. Before him in the water a long thin bar of light appears. looks at it amazed. Voices are heard singing very far awa He reaches out to touch the long strip of light but his h just disturbs the water. It is a reflection. The strip gr wider and the ethereal music is closer. Perceval looks up. The strip of light is before him,  suspended, thirty feet above. It continues to grow wider. drawbridge is being slowly lowered, allowing a powerful l to escape from within. Perceval is terrified. In pain, he slowly rises into the  saddle, ready to gallop off; but fascinated, hypnotized b the sight, he cannot, and he stays and watches. The dim outline of a castle becomes visible as the drawbr is lowered across the water to the ground at his feet. At the center of the blast of light coming from the castle,  Perceval can make out a burning chalice. The music swells a terrifying pitch, searing the forest.

At the sight of the chalice, Perceval masters his fear. B in light and music, he spurs the horse forward onto the  drawbridge. Once he is on it, the bridge begins to rise. Unsure of it footing and blinded by the light, the horse becomes skitt and Perceval has to struggle to control it. He dismounts lead it, but the horse is terrified, rears up and jumps o the bridge, which continues to rise, drawn up by unseen h Perceval hesitates, then advances down the sloping drawbr into the castle courtyard. All details are bleached out b the blinding light. The chalice appears suspended in spac and now the figure of a man can be glimpsed standing behi it. Enchanting music from unseen singers grows and weaves.  Perceval looks back to see the drawbridge slowly closing, trapping him inside. He approaches the figure, his courage ebbing. Hands cuppi the chalice, it speaks to him.
What is the secret of the chalice?  Who does it serve?

Perceval doesn't understand. He glances back again. The  drawbridge is nearly closed. Terror seizes him. Panicked, puzzled, baffled, he backs away. He scrambles u the drawbridge desperate to reach the top before it close He claws his way up till his hand grasps the top. He heav himself through the narrow closing slit which is about to crush him. He screams, and with a final effort he wriggle free and topples over crashing into the water below.

He looks up. The drawbridge thunders shut, the last thin  strip of light disappearing; and now he is surrounded onl by the silence of the forest. Where there was a castle, now there is darkness. Perceval wades through the water. He has crossed the stream and al he can see and feel are tree trunks. The castle has  disappeared. He is utterly defeated.
The chalice. The secret was in my  grasp. I let it slip, afraid for  myself. A question was asked. I didn't  understand. I didn't try. I failed...
"Nine years passed."
Dripping water is steadily encrusting the crystal with  limestone.

location: HALL OF THE ROUND TABLE, CAMELOT

text: Dead knights lay on biers. The once glorious seat of powe is falling into decay. Few are in attendance around the t Agitated, Kay enters and goes to Arthur, who is worn and  haggard, and aged.
Your son Mordred is at the gate.
Arthur comes alive.
At last...
Don't recognize him. You were trapped  by Morgana's sorcery.

(staring off) ...Gawain and Perceval, Bors and  Bohort, Caradoc and Ector, and all  the others--lost to me. Only the  echo of their voices remains in this  empty hall. All I have left is the  memory of their fellowship. Echoes  and memories. I am a ghost of the  King that once was... (he turns to Kay and  with sudden harshness) ...Mordred is real, alive, my own  flesh and blood. I will see him, I  must.

The drawbridge lowers slowly, and Arthur moves away from and the other knights, and advances across it. Rooks wheel over the dead trees of the forest that surrou Camelot. A group of armed men waits at the edge of the fo One steps forward, a huge knight in black armor, the meta defining and exaggerating the powerful musculature of his body. He is Mordred, a young man of eighteen, and of  extraordinary beauty. A page follows ten steps behind him bearing an enormous spear, its points hooded. Arthur stop at the edge of the drawbridge, the huge knight a few step from him. Kay, ready for anything, moves halfway across t drawbridge. Mordred kneels on one knee.
Father...
Rise, Mordred.
I have come to claim what is mine,  Father.
I recognize you only as my son, no  more.

(his tone is scathing) And you are the great King? The lords  have rebelled. Invaders attack the  coasts. Crops don't grow. There is  nothing but plague and hunger in the  land. Only I am feared. I will be  king. You may have lost Excalibur,  but I have found my own weapon of  power. There.
He points to the huge lance. The page pulls a string and hood drops, revealing a diabolically sharp spear tip, its metal glinting menacingly.
The very spear that pierced the side  of Christ as he died on the cross.
Your mother told you that?
Mordred is thrown off by the doubt Arthur has cast. Arthu looks upon his son, desperately trying to read him.
I cannot offer you the land, only my  love...
And I offer only this, Father. To  commit with passion and pleasure all  the evils that you failed to commit,  as man and king.
Arthur goes forward to embrace his son, a desperate attem Mordred recoils.
We will embrace only in battle.  Father, and I will touch you only  with the blade of my spear.
Arthur is on the verge of tears.
I will muster a great force of  knights, and I will return to fight  for what is mine.
So be it.
He turns and re-enters the castle, the drawbridge pulled immediately behind him. He is hunched over, broken.

Asleep in the saddle, Perceval rides across burnt and  smoldering fields. The horse walks aimlessly; it is the s animal, mangy and old. A hoard of children in filthy rags closes in on him, begging, pulling at the horse's trappin He bolts awake and reins away. His eyes are red and fever Wild hope grips him when he sees a glinting light by a  farmhouse. He spurs the horse forward into a gallop.

He leaps from the saddle and a terrified woman backs away Perceval plunges his hand into the source of light. It is nothing but the reflection of the dying sun in a bucketfu of water. Perceval covers his face.
Illusions. I will never find it  again... I am sorry, woman, that I  frightened you.
Peasants have emerged, surrounding him, and they hold axe and pitchforks.
Good woman, do you have any food?  Some water?...
The little we had, we gave to  Mordred's knights. He has taken this  land. Tell the King that now we must  look to Mordred.
But we will give you some water...
At least ten peasants encircle Perceval and he is too  exhausted to put up a fight. They grab him and carry him  away. Other peasants pull his horse to the ground, and on raises and ax to kill it.
They throw Perceval down an escarpment and he rolls into fast-moving water. He is swept downstream and thrown  ferociously against the rocks in the stream bed, crying o in pain.

The water is deeper and Perceval is dragged under by the  weight of his armor. He struggles desperately to shed it, half drowning. Exhausted, he pulls himself up onto the muddy shore besid rotting sheep carcass, and around him, the daylight dies.
Ragged and bruised, lifeless, he stares into space.
I have lost my horse, my armor, my  sword. I have lost my way. I have  lost my strength. I have lost  everything... I will not lose hope.

A light bursting through the trees shines on the mud,  wordless, harmonies sound somewhere in the forest. Percev sets off toward the source. The burning light blasts into his face but he doesn't fli The chorus builds in power. Before him, a drawbridge lowe
He steps onto the bridge and walks in. He crosses the  courtyard as the drawbridge closes behind him. All detail of the castle are bleached out by the searing light.
He steps onto the bridge and walks in. He crosses the  courtyard as the drawbridge closes behind him. All detail of the castle are bleached out by the searing light.

Heading for the source of the light he ascends what seem be a staircase. He enters a hall where the chalice stands suspended, burning with light, and the mysterious music s and grows. Perceval approaches the diaphanous and featureless Figure who stands over the chalice.
Who does it serve?
You, my lord.
I have waited long for you. Once you  almost saw, but fear blinded you.  Why am I served from the chalice?
Because you and the land are one.
I am wasting away and I cannot die.  And I cannot live.
You and the land are one. Drink from  the chalice. You will be reborn and  the land with you.
